Implementation  
In accordance with the law, the Articles of Association and Terms of Reference, the Supervisory Board adopted a candidate 
profile for the members of the Management Board, based on a proposal from the Nomination Committee. This profile takes 
into account an “Expertise and Capabilities Matrix”, specifying, among other things, the required knowledge, skills and 
experience to perform the tasks as Management Board member, in order to successfully develop and implement the bank’s 
strategy in the respective market or the respective division and as a management body collectively. The Management 
Board reviews succession plans for Management Board positions, both individually and as a group. Individual succession 
plans are reviewed and internal succession candidates are discussed in detail based on potential, leadership skills and 
experience as well as fit and proper suitability. As gender diversity is a key focus of Deutsche Bank, the respective 
succession metrics and data analytics support this process. After approval by the Management Board these plans are 
submitted to the Nomination Committee and the Supervisory Board in principle at a meeting for extensive deliberation. 
In identifying candidates to fill a position on the bank’s Management Board, the Supervisory Board’s Nomination 
Committee takes into account the appropriate diversity balance of all Management Board members collectively. 
Furthermore, it also considers the targets set by the Supervisory Board in accordance with statutory requirements for the 
percentage of women on the Management Board.  
The Nomination Committee supports the Supervisory Board with the periodic assessment, to be performed at least once 
a year, of the knowledge, skills and experience of the individual members of the Management Board and of the 
Management Board in its entirety.

Non-GAAP financial measures 
This document and other documents the Group has published or may publish contain Non-GAAP financial measures. Non-
GAAP financial measures are measures of the Group’s historical or future performance, financial position or cash flows that 
contain adjustments that exclude or include amounts that are included or excluded, as the case may be, from the most 
directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS in the Group’s financial statements.  
Return on Equity Ratios 
The Group reports a post-tax return on average shareholders’ equity and a post-tax return on average tangible 
shareholders’ equity, each of which is a Non-GAAP financial measure. 
The post-tax returns on average shareholders’ equity and average tangible shareholders' equity are calculated as profit 
(loss) attributable to Deutsche Bank shareholders after profit (loss) attributable to additional equity components (AT1 
coupon) as a percentage of average shareholders’ equity and average tangible shareholders' equity, respectively. 
Profit (loss) attributable to Deutsche Bank shareholders after profit (loss) attributable to additional equity components 
(AT1 coupon) for the segments is a Non-GAAP financial measure and is defined as profit (loss) excluding post-tax profit 
(loss) attributable to noncontrolling interests and after profit (loss) attributable to additional equity components (AT1 
coupon), which are allocated to segments based on their allocated average tangible shareholders’ equity. For the Group, 
it reflects the reported effective tax rate, which was 34% for the full year 2024, 14% for 2023 and (1)% for 2022. For the 
segments, the applied tax rate was 28% for all report periods in 2024, 2023 and 2022.  
At the Group level, tangible shareholders' equity is shareholders’ equity as reported in the Consolidated Balance Sheet 
excluding goodwill and other intangible assets. Tangible shareholders’ equity for the segments is calculated by deducting 
goodwill and other intangible assets from shareholders’ equity as allocated to the segments. Shareholders’ equity and 
tangible shareholders’ equity are presented on an average basis. 
The Group believes that a presentation of average tangible shareholders’ equity makes comparisons to its competitors 
easier and refers to this measure in the return on equity ratios presented by the Group. However, average tangible 
shareholders’ equity is not a measure provided for in IFRS, and the Group’s ratios based on this measure should not be 
compared to other companies’ ratios without considering differences in the calculations.

Revenues excluding specific items 
Revenues excluding specific items is a performance indicator that is a Non-GAAP financial measure most directly 
comparable to the IFRS financial measure net revenues. Revenues excluding specific items is calculated by adjusting net 
revenues under IFRS for specific revenue items which generally fall outside the usual nature or scope of the business and 
are likely to distort an accurate assessment of the divisional operating performance. Excluded items are Debt Valuation 
Adjustment (DVA) and material transactions or events that are either one-off in nature or belong to a portfolio of connected 
transactions or events where the P&L impact is limited to a specific period of time. The Group believes that a presentation 
of net revenues excluding the impact of these items provides a more meaningful depiction of the revenues associated with 
the business.

AUDIT CERTIFICATE 
Report on the consolidated financial statements 
We have audited the consolidated financial statements of Steiermärkische Bank und Sparkassen Aktiengesellschaft, 
Graz, and its subsidiaries (the Group), comprising the consolidated statement of financial position as at 
31 December 2024, the consolidated income statement, the consolidated statement of comprehensive income, the 
consolidated statement of changes in equity and the consolidated statement of cash flows for the fiscal year then 
ended and the notes to the consolidated financial statements. 
In our opinion, the attached consolidated financial statements comply with the relevant statutory provisions and give 
as true and fair a view as possible of the net assets and financial position as at 31 December 2024 and of the results 
of operations and cash flows of the Group for the fiscal year ending on this date in accordance with the International 
Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), as applicable in the EU, the additional requirements of section 245a of the 
Austrian Commercial Code (UGB) and the Austrian Banking Act. 
Basis for the audit opinion 
We conducted our audit in accordance with EU Regulation No. 537/2014 (hereinafter EU Regulation) and the Austrian 
generally accepted standards for the audit of financial statements. These standards require the application of the 
International Standards on Auditing (ISA). Our responsibilities according to these regulations and standards are 
described in more detail in the section “Responsibilities of the auditor of the annual financial statements for the 
auditing of the annual financial statements” of our audit opinion. We are independent of the Group in compliance with 
the Austrian provisions under corporate, special and professional law, and we have met our other professional 
obligations in compliance with these requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained up until the 
date of this audit certificate is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion on this date. 
Particularly important auditing circumstances 
Particularly important auditing circumstances are those circumstances that according to our due discretion were most 
important for our auditing of the consolidated annual financial statements of the fiscal year. These matters were 
considered in connection with our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole and the formulation of our 
audit opinion, and we do not provide a separate audit opinion on these matters. 
Impairments to loans and advances to customers (expected credit losses) 
Circumstances 
Impairment on credit exposures represents the management’s best estimate of expected credit loss from the credit 
portfolio at the end of the reporting period. 
For loans and advances to customers in the amount of EUR 14,764.2 million that are valued at amortised cost, 
Steiermärkische Bank und Sparkassen Aktiengesellschaft, Graz, as of 31 December 2024 formed risk provisions in 
the amount of EUR 418.7 million to cover impairments.  
To determine expected credit losses, Steiermärkische Bank und Sparkasse Aktiengesellschaft, Graz, implemented 
internal guidelines and specific processes. The assumptions and estimates to be made by the management during the 
process to determine expected credit losses are complex and are subject to considerable discretionary powers. 
The models developed and implemented to calculate impairment are specifically for the individual credit portfolios. 
Both for products and the economic environment, there are country-specific and future-oriented features that are 
relevant for the respective loss estimate, which results in an increased complexity of models and inputs. The 
uncertainties inherent to the estimate of impairments of loans and advances, in particular the consideration of future 
economic relationships, are also increased in 2024 due to the geopolitical and economic situation. 
Steiermärkische Bank und Sparkassen Aktiengesellschaft, Graz, has taken this circumstance into account through 
collective allocation of stages and in-model adjustment (overlays).

of methods and processes that were applied in order to record the increased uncertainties in the current and future 
environment in the expected loan losses. 
• evaluated the control activities in the credit risk management and in the credit business processes and tested key 
controls, in particular with regard to credit approval, ongoing monitoring and the early warning system and recorded 
and critically appraised the processes relating to the early detection of default and the UTP assessment (“unlikely to

• analysed the sensitivities and effects of the model aspects specific to IFRS 9. 
• evaluated whether key components of the expected credit loss calculation are correctly incorporated into the models 
by conducting walk-throughs and reviewing control tables..

Boundary conditions 
With inflation that was greatly reduced compared to the previous year, Austria’s economy found itself in recession for 
a second year in 2024. Gross domestic product (GDP) fell (provisionally) by up to 0.9% due to weak developments in 
industry and construction. In the euro zone, however, GDP increased by 0.8%. 
The inflation rate in Austria was 2.9%, after 7.8% in 2023, on a yearly average. In the course of the months, however, 
inflation fell substantially so that it was even close to the ECB’s target, at 1.9% in November and 2.0% in December. 
The high difference in inflation compared to the eurozone was thus no longer an issue. Prices for household energy 
that fell in a year-by-year comparison slowed inflation most.  
The value added of all Austrian sectors developed negatively overall in 2024, at -1.0%. Declining industrial production 
(-4.4%, of which -3.6% in construction) was in contrast to an expansive service sector overall (+0.5%). Financial and 
insurance services as part of the service sector achieved an increase of +6.1%. Expansion in the transport sector 
(+0.3%) was just above zero. Retail (-2.0%) shrank as it had done in the previous year, whereas agriculture and 
forestry (+3.0%) and the health and social sector (+1.5%) increased. 
The weak development in Germany encumbered Austria’s foreign trade so that both exports (-2.9%) and imports (-
2.5%) declined. The current account balance achieved a slightly higher value, at 2.4% of GDP after 1.3% in the prior 
year. 
The high level of uncertainty hindered the investments by companies that were -2.9% below the figure for the previous 
year. Private consumption (-0.3%) also declined as private households only noticed the heavy fall in inflation with 
some delay and remained frugal despite good increases in collective agreements. 
The negative economic development also made itself felt on the Austrian labour market. The number of employees in 
active dependent employment increased by approx. +0.6% to 3,932,059 men and women and the number of 
unemployed and people in training increased perceptibly by +6.8% to 426,012 people. The unemployment rate in 
Austria (according to the Eurostat definition) grew from 5.1% in the provisional yearly average to 5.2% in 2024 (until 
the status in November) but remained below the comparative figure of the European Union (at a provisional 6.0%). 
At 6,550 cases, the number of company bankruptcies was significantly higher in 2024 than in 2023 (+22%). Retail, 
construction and the hotel and restaurant sectors were the most heavily affected. The number of private bankruptcies 
applied for was slightly higher (+0.8%) than in the previous year, at 8,920 cases. The bankruptcy liabilities were also 
above the comparative figure of the previous year. 
The Maastricht limits were substantially exceeded in the public budget and government debt. According to the current 
figures from the third quarter of 2024, Austria’s public debt amounted to 83.2% of GDP or EUR 398.4 billion in 2024, 
whereby according to the Maastricht contracts a maximum of 60% is agreed. In the previous year, the comparative 
value was EUR 371.7 billion or 78.6% of GDP and thus substantially lower. 
According to forecasts, the state’s budget deficit increased in 2024 to (provisionally) 3.7% of GDP; the Maastricht 
objective is a maximum of 3%. On the income side, consumption taxes developed only very marginally, depending on 
private consumption. The elimination of the cold progression and the low corporation tax volume also had a negative 
effect. On the expenditure side, the flood disaster, the construction economy package and higher pension payments 
and staff costs due to inflation led to an additional burden. 
Due to falling inflation and the weak economy in the eurozone, the ECB reduced the deposit rate in four steps in June, 
September, October and December 2024 by 0.25 percentage points in each case, from 4.0% to 3.0% now. Austrian 
banks’ interest rates rose in 2024, for both lending and the deposit business. In the new business, however, the 
lending interest rates did not increase any further. 
The banks were able to selectively expand their lending despite the recession. The domestic loan volume increased 
by 1.1%. Corporate financing increased (+1.8%) whereas private loans declined in 2024 (-1.2%). In the case of

Readiness for the green transition 
As part of Erste Group Bank AG, the Sparkassen are among the leading banks in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) 
and are committed to mobilising finances for a climate-resilient, lower-carbon and fairer society. As one of the first 
members of the Net Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), objectives were drawn up for a net-zero portfolio by 2050 and net-
zero banking operations by 2030. Sustainability is one of the most important pillars of the Sparkassen’s overall 
strategy. 
The Sparkassen have examined the environment in which they are active and carried out an analysis in order to 
evaluate the resilience of the Sparkassen’s business model to risks and its readiness for opportunities that arise from 
the necessary changeover to a lower-carbon economy. In addition, the potential effects, risks and opportunities were 
examined using a double materiality analysis that arise from climate change and environmental risks. 
Austria is one of the countries with a medium performance in the climate protection index. The successes up to now 
in the area of climate protection, such as the goal to achieve climate neutrality by 2040, are positive. Some of the 
laws required to curb climate change and for adaptation to climate change (such as the Energy Efficiency Act and the 
Act on Renewable Heating) were adopted in 2023. Unfortunately, Austria is not on a path to achieving its ambitious 
goal of climate neutrality by 2040. Up to now, the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions is not reconcilable with 
Austria’s binding goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the sectors outside of the EU emissions trading 
systems by 2030 by 36% compared to the previous year. Even taking into account the additional measures that were 
considered for the period 2021-2030, the country is running the risk of missing this goal by 9 percentage points. 
Before 2020, the emission reductions in the energy and industry sector were offset by an increase in the end energy 
consumption in buildings and in transport that have a considerable potential for reductions in emissions. Currently, 
Austria is an important transit country for road transport crossing the Alps. The reduction of transport-related 
emissions will be particularly important for the transition to carbon neutrality.

Austria is leading in renewable energies. 81% of its electricity mix consists of renewable energies, primarily from hydro 
power. Nevertheless, considerable investments are still required in Austria in order to reach the goal of 100%

the Austrian energy mix is 34.9%. Austria is above the EU average in the electrification of road transport and the share

With regard to the social dimension of the green transition, the guaranteeing of the access to fundamental transport 
and energy services seems to present a lesser challenge in Austria, compared to other Member States. 
The “Future of Growth” report by the World Economic Forum in January 2024 lists seven archetypes of growth paths 
(A-G). These archetypes of the growth path are not closed groups with precise boundaries; rather, they constitute an 
intuitive approach to emphasising relevant common growth experiences between groups of countries (scores 0-100). 
Archetype A, which Austria belongs to, is characteristic for a group of economies with a high income that are defined 
by a strong performance in the pillars Inclusivity (74.1), Innovative Ability (70.6) and Resilience (66.7). The value of 
the archetype for sustainability (54.1) is substantially weaker than the performance in the other pillars, and it is also 
characterised by a moderate per capital GDP growth of 0.7% in the last five years. The profile of the archetype 
indicates a strong push in the direction of greater inclusivity and innovative ability as well as in the development of 
resilience but, although the sustainability performance is above the global average, there is still potential for further 
progress. 
This has the following effects on the Sparkassen: 
1. Net-zero obligation The ambitious goal of the European Union to achieve net zero by 2050 depends on the 
decarbonisation measures of the individual Member States, in particular in the Central and Eastern European area. 
2. Need for investment: The change required in Austria demands comprehensive investments and risk sharing that 
necessitate both EU funds and financial assistance from the private sector. 
3. Compliance with statutory regulations: The regulations being further developed on climate change are forcing 
corporate customers to introduce sustainable practices and to comply with strict environmental standards, which 
requires considerable adjustments in their processes, supply chains and reporting. The Sparkassen also have to 
comply with these regulations and to adapt by integrating the new requirements in their business model, improving 
transparency and implementing robust sustainability strategies. 
4. Energy transition: Fundamental for the decarbonisation of electricity generation, heating and all other energy-
intensive industries. This will reduce emissions, promote economic growth, drive innovations and create jobs. 
5. Decarbonisation of real estate: The improvement in the energy performance of buildings through renovations is of 
decisive importance, in particular overcoming challenges such as limited subsidies, financial affordability and technical 
obstacles. 
6. Financial administration: A balance between the speed of the transition and the social/economic costs is of decisive 
importance. 
7. Overcoming physical risks in own and customer’s portfolio: As river flooding and heat stress constitute considerable 
risks, the adaptation measures need to be expanded and business opportunities created. On the risk side, the gap in 
insurance cover needs to be closely monitored and well managed. 
8. Non-environment-related risks: Opportunities arise in areas such as the loss of biodiversity, environmental pollution, 
waste and water management that offer growth potential for sustainable financing. 
9. Transition and sustainable financing: The growing demand for green bonds and loans and for transition financing, 
together with the commitment to sustainable financing, supports the role of the Sparkassen as a pioneer in the 
transition to a low-carbon economy.

Corporate social responsibility  
There is no co-existence without responsibility for one another. This applies for any form of relationship, including the 
relationship of a company to society. Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) denotes precisely this responsibility that 
companies assume for society. Steiermärkische Sparkasse has been living this philosophy since 1825 and also links 
specific goals to it, namely sustainable value creation and capital protection for its customers.  
This is only possible if two prerequisites are met: Firstly, the opportunities and risks need to be taken into account that 
arise from the economic, ecological and social boundary conditions. Secondly, the aim is to incorporate all relevant 
interest groups. These are in particular customers, employees and business partners. 
Corporate Social Responsibility is closely associated with the concept of sustainability. In 2021, the Management 
Board decided to adopt a holistic sustainability strategy that takes effect precisely there and incorporates the three 
pillars economy, ecology and social matters. The logical areas for action are derived from these: environment, 
employees, customers as well as society and Corporate Governance. The sustainability strategy was adapted in 2024 
and in particular adjusted due to the result of the double materiality analysis conducted within the framework of the 
project to implement the CSRD.  
Each area of action of the sustainability strategy covers topics that are driven forward by specific goals, measures 
and activities. Clearly defined goals and the permanent review of the goals and processes define the path into the 
future. This thus also ensures that Steiermärkische Sparkasse can comply with the specifications of the Sustainability 
and Diversity Improvement Act, whereby Steiermärkische Sparkasse is currently still included in the consolidated non-
financial declaration of ERSTE Group Bank AG. After the transposing of the Corporate Sustainability Reporting 
Directive (CSRD) in Austrian law (NaBeG), it is to be assumed that Steiermärkische Sparkasse is obligated to create 
its own non-financial declaration.

sustainable products both in investment and in financing. But it also means even more, namely advising and supporting 
customers when they want to integrate sustainability in their financial decisions or accompanying them in

With regard to the explanations of the risks and the goals and methods in the risk management, reference is made to

Internal control and risk management system for the Group accounting process  
General 
The "Internal Control System" (ICS) denotes processes designed by the company management and implemented in 
the company by means of which 
 the effectiveness and economic efficiency of operating activities (including the protection of assets from loss due 
to damage or misappropriation), 
 the reliability of financial reporting and 
 compliance with the statutory regulations relevant for the company  
are monitored and checked. 
The risk management incorporates all processes that serve to identify, analyse and evaluate risks and to take 
measures that prevent the attainment of the company's goals being impaired by fundamental risks that arise.  
According to the internationally recognised COSO framework (COSO – Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the 
Treadway Commission – is a voluntary private-sector organisation in the USA that aims to help improve the quality of 
financial reporting through ethical action, effective internal controls and good corporate governance) for the 
organisation of risk management systems, the ICS is to be understood as part of a company-wide risk management 
system. These also include the management and the control of risks that relate to the correctness and reliability of 
the accounting. 
Taking into account the COSO framework and the 3 Lines of Defense model, the ICS policy stipulates the general 
framework conditions for the Internal Control System, the standards for tasks and responsibilities and the minimum 
criteria for the ICS documentation. The objective of the internal control system is to assist management to enable it 
to ensure effective and continuously improving internal controls with regard to the objectives of the ICS described 
above. 
Control environment 
The control environment represents the framework for the introduction, application and monitoring of ICS principles, 
procedures and measures. The Management Board is responsible for the setting up, configuration and application of 
an internal control and risk management system that is appropriate to the company's requirements with regard to the 
accounting process. 
The organisational structure provides for a clear profile of requirements for Accounting operations. In the process, 
cross-divisional key functions are controlled centrally via Steiermärkische Sparkasse, whereby at the same time the 
individual subsidiaries have a high degree of autonomy. The functions of departments substantially involved in the 
financial reporting process are clearly separated and responsibilities are clearly allocated.

In addition, fundamental subsidiaries have their own accounting departments that work in close consultation with the 
Accounting division. The responsibilities of the Accounting division incorporate primarily the creation of the individual 
and consolidated annual and interim financial statements as well as the annual financial statements of some 
subsidiaries, the financial accounting and the transfer pricing, taxes and reporting pursuant to supervisory law. The 
Accounting division is responsible for the regulatory competence regarding all questions of accounting and the 
specialist instruction authority to ensure the application of standards that are uniform throughout the Group. To 
support the operational implementation, Group guidelines have been drawn up by the Erste Group that are to be

Risk assessment  
The key processes in the Accounting division are subjected to an annual risk evaluation and risk assessment within 
the framework of the ICS process. The main risk in the financial reporting process is that issues are not presented in 
a manner consistent with the financial position and financial performance due to error or intent (fraud). This is the 
case when the information in the statement of financial position, income statement and notes deviates substantially 
from the correct values and can entail serious consequences such as financial damage, penalties imposed by the 
banking authority, or loss or reputation. 
Control measures 
With regard to the financial reporting process, the internal control and risk management system includes operating 
instructions and processes for:  
 the correct and appropriate documentation of business transaction, including the use of the Group assets, 
 the recording of all information necessary to draw up annual financial statements and 
 to prevent non-approved acquisitions or sales that could have a fundamental effect on the annual financial 
statements. 
The following are deemed to be elementary components of the Internal Control System within the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group: 
 Controlling as the permanent financial and business analysis and management of the company or individual company 
divisions,  
 Automatic control facilities and measures that are intrinsic to the system in the formal process organisation and 
organisational structure, e.g. programmed checks in data processing or downstream checks indicated in an ICS tool.  
 separation of functions and dual control principles; 
 Internal Audit – as an independent organisational unit – that monitors all departments, particularly with regard to the 
effectiveness of components of the internal control system, and strives to do so independently of processes, yet as 
close to operations as possible.  
The accounting of Steiermärkische Sparkasse and the main domestic subsidiaries as well as the subsidiary banks in 
North Macedonia and Bosnia is carried out in SAP FI. The closing data transmitted by the foreign Group entities directly 
into the consolidation system are first checked for plausibility in the Accounting division. The further consolidation 
steps are then done in the consolidation system (TAGETIK). These incorporate, among others, the capital consolidation, 
the consolidation of expenses and income, as well as debt consolidation. Fundamental interim gains through Group 
postings are then eliminated. Subsequently, the preparation of the notes in accordance with IFRS and the 
Bankwesengesetz (BWG – Austrian Federal Banking Act) and Unternehmensgesetzbuch (UGB – Austrian Commercial 
Code) constitutes the conclusion of consolidation. In-house solutions are also used for the preparation of these 
disclosures and the editing and layout of the notes. The accounting systems and the upstream applications are 
protected by access authorisations and automatic control steps as well as manual steps that are envisaged as 
mandatory in the process. 
Through the obligation of all Group companies (all domestic and foreign banks and financial institutions) to report their 
actual and forecast results to the Accounting and Controlling and ALM divisions during the year on a monthly basis, 
deviations between plan and actual figures during the year are recognised in a timely manner and there is the 
opportunity to respond accordingly.

Report on the expected development of the company  
Boundary conditions in light of the geopolitical crisis in Europe 
After the reference date for the statement of financial position (31.12.2024), the majority of the risks for the growth 
forecasts are directed upwards. As in the prior year, the risks include unsolved conflicts such as in the Gaza Strip and 
the ongoing war in Ukraine. The downward risks also include the weak economy in China and the tensions with the 
US with regard to the promised more restrictive customs policy. At the same time, European fiscal rules could result 
in a rapid consolidation of public budgets in several countries and slow the economy further. In Austria, a longer-
lasting recession in industry coupled with an even greater increase in corporate bankruptcies could lead to a greater 
lay-off of personnel. The resulting higher unemployment could slow the forecast moderate economic upturn which is 
fundamentally sustained by the consumption expenses of private households.  
However, to date, no events are known after the reference date for the statement of financial position that would have 
resulted in a different depiction of the 2024 annual financial statements. 
In the basic scenario, the current forecasts by the Economic Research Institute (WIFO) and the Institute for Higher 
Studies (IHS) assume that growth in Austrian GDP will return in 2025 again to a low but positive growth path, at a 
maximum +0.7%. Fundamental reasons are impulses from abroad and the economic package at home, which 
construction investments should profit from. In 2026, the forecasts are assuming further economic recovery (GDP 
maximum +1.3%). 
Inflation already fell substantially in 2024. According to forecasts, a further reduction to between 2.3% and 2.6% is 
probable in 2025. There will be an attainment of the target figure of the ECB of nearly 2.0% from 2026 onwards. 
The situation on the labour market remained relatively stable in 2024 despite the recession. According to the WIFO 
forecast, the unemployment rate should be 5.4% in 2025 (according to the Eurostat definition) and slightly decline to 
5.2% in 2026. In the forecast, the IHS assumes 5.5% (2025) and 5.2% (2026).  
In the banking market, the growth forecast of the IHS 2025 for loans is at +1.2% lower than with deposits, at +2.0%. 
Companies are barely investing and accordingly, the demand for loans is weak. Private households are reticent with 
their consumption, which is why the savings quota is high and favours growth in deposits and/or also (early) 
repayments of private loans. In 2026, the increase in the credit volume should remain moderate, at +1.3%. With 
deposits, an increase of only +0.6% is forecast. 
Although the ECB does not communicate any specific information on future interest rate decisions, representatives of 
the monetary and capital markets are assuming that there will be a further three reductions in interest rates in 2025, 
totalling 75 base points. The reason for this is the strongly declining inflation rate in the euro zone. 
 
Anticipated development of the company  
In its planning assumptions, Steiermärkische Sparkasse assumed that the three-month Euribor on an annual average 
in 2025 will fall substantially in accordance with the interest rate policy of the ECB. Falling interest rates should have 
a correspondingly positive effect for investors in securities. This under the assumption that share prices will only 
fluctuate within the framework of the conventional volatility, but not fall in the long term. Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
is thus planning higher commission results in the securities business in 2025 too. In payment transactions, the 
Sparkasse also sees increasing potential for income which results from a higher number of customers and the price 
increases from indexings.  
With deposits, Steiermärkische Sparkasse, in line with the strong increase in the savings quota to 11.4%, initially sees 
a continuing dynamic volume development on the market. A fundamental reason for this is the weak consumption 
willingness of the private households who are frugal in situations of high economic uncertainty. In the corporate 
segment, the cumulated liquidity does not initially flow into investments that quickly. At the earliest from 2026 onwards, 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse is assuming lower deposit growth again in line with assumptions regarding lower interest 
rates.

22
With receivables from customers, the goal continues to be to expand growth in the planning period slightly above the 
market. That is why gains in market shares are strived for both in the retail but also in the commercial division. With 
residential mortgages, a further recovery of the demand for mortgages is to be anticipated, whereby the lower interest 
rates and the housing package of the government provide corresponding support. A certain downward risk results 
from the construction of new apartments that would be delayed even further in a recession. In the case of consumer 
loans, it is planned to achieve the pre-pandemic level again after the lows in the previous years. Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse would like to continue to support corporate customers in financing the real economy. However, the credit 
volume should only now grow in the low one-digit percentage range.  
In 2025, on the expenses side, Steiermärkische Sparkasse is planning an increase in the personnel costs due to the 
increases set out in the collective agreements that will be oriented to the inflation rate of 2024.  
The planned operating result in 2025 is planned to be lower than the figure for the previous year due to the decline in 
the interest surplus, despite the ambitious plan for commissions. 
The increased risk costs in 2025 are associated with the upward trend in insolvencies and the weak economic outlook. 
With the increasing stabilisation of the economy in the further course of the planning period, it is assumed that the 
risk costs will level off a normal level again. 
In the 2025 fiscal year too, the aim is to grow continuously and risk-consciously on the basis of the existing business 
model. The activities aimed at customer acquisition will continue to be pursued with unchanged intensity.  
A fundamental success factor here will be the further integration of new technologies in the business model and sales 
concept of Steiermärkische Sparkasse. A decisive added value is to be created for customers through intelligent 
linking of digital services and personal consultation. Here, the focus is on the financial health of all customers. It is our 
aspiration to make a financially self-determined life possible for people. Long-standing customer relationships and 
partnerships are key factors here for success. 
The expansion of Private Banking into a competence focus area will continue to be consistently pursued at the Group 
parent in Austria. 
A special focus will continue to be placed on the active support of transformation processes and investments for more 
sustainability and the best possible accompaniment of our customers on this path. In the Commercial business, a 
special focus is on the financing of investments for the growth-oriented transformation of the business model. 
In total, a balanced growth in all sectors is strived for. 
A negative scenario for 2025 would be a continuation of the recession. However, the very high capital base and the 
good liquidity situation of Steiermärkische Sparkasse make it possible to counter the uncertain boundary conditions 
and to be a reliable partner for the customers and people in the region in the future too. In the entire planning period, 
the capital quotas have sufficient buffer, both towards the regulatory minimum requirements to be anticipated and 
also to the higher internal target figures. 
Formation of risk provisions  
The special risks of the credit business is being taken into appropriate account by the formation of risk provisions (loss 
allowances for statement of financial position credit transactions and provisions for off-balance-sheet credit 
transactions). The formation of risk provisions must correspond to the guidelines according to IFRS 9.  
In the process, the expected loss will be determined for receivables not classified as impaired either as a 1-year 
expected credit loss (Stage 1) or as a lifetime expected credit loss (Stage 2). Financial instruments when recorded for 
the first time and/or financial instruments without a significant increase in the credit risks since they were recorded 
for the first time are assigned to Stage 1; however, financial instruments with a significant increase of the credit risk 
since they were recorded for the first time and financial instruments without sufficient information about when they 
were recorded for the first time are assigned to Stage 2. The determination whether there , is a significant increase in 
the credit risk since initial recognition will be determined by the review of qualitative and quantitative criteria.

ANNUAL FINANCIAL REPORT 2024 – STEIERMÄRKISCHE SPARKASSE GROUP 
23
Quantitative criteria are the relative or absolute change in the current annualised Lifetime PD (probability of default) 
of the financial instrument compared to the annualised Lifetime PD to the time of accrual of the financial instrument. 
Qualitative criteria are e.g. the handover of the customer to Workout, the setting of a forbearance status or overdrawn 
by more than 30 days. 
The risk provisions for defaulted receivables from customers are calculated generally on the individual customer level. 
The individual method is used in material defaulted customer receivables and consists of an individual determination 
of the reorganisation or resolution scenarios currently seen as possible, their probabilities of occurrence and the return 
flows to be expected depending on the scenario (repayments and collateral income) by the workout risk manager. The 
present value results from the discounting of the expected payment streams with the original effective interest rate. 
The necessary risk provision results from the difference between gross carrying value and the present value of the 
expected payment streams in a scenario, calculated across all probability-weighted scenarios. A customer who has 
defaulted is classified as significant if the entire receivables and off-balance-sheet items are above a certain 
materiality threshold. 
Otherwise, the customer is classified as insignificant, whereby a rule-based approach is taken for the calculation of 
the risk provision. Statistically determined risk parameters are used for the anticipated loss of a customer classified 
as “insignificant”, depending on the duration of the default and the status in the restructuring and resolution process, 
the potential restructuring or resolution scenarios, their probabilities of occurrence and the return flows to be expected 
with these. 
For all receivables for which there is no impairment, a formula-based calculation of the individual expected loss (at the 
level of financial instruments), taking into account the expected return flows, is used, based on statistically determined 
risk parameters. 
On the basis of future-oriented information, current circumstances and forward-looking information (in particular 
regarding current macroeconomic scenarios), new evaluations of the risk parameters are being made. 
Due to multiple crises in the last few years and their different effects on economic development, a collective 
assessment of the significant increase in the credit risk (stage overlays) was applied at the end of December 2024 in 
addition to the standard appraisal of future-related information. This led to a shift in Stage 2 on the basis of predefined 
portfolio characteristics. This approach was agreed in the Sparkassen sector and approved by the respective 
management committees of the Sparkasse. Exceptions to the collective assessment of the significant increase in the 
credit risk were necessary if special characteristics were established and it was duly documented why they behave 
differently to the rest of the portfolio. 
Certain industry sectors are susceptible to the upheavals of the current environment of multiple crises with geopolitical 
and macroeconomic shocks. The continuing high inflation and the reduction in available income continue to slow 
private consumption, whereas the great global uncertainty and the high refinancing conditions are having negative 
effects on investments and industrial activity. Whereas certain sectors have developed robustly, others still see 
themselves confronted with high warehouse stocks, ongoing problems in the supply chain and a cost inflation as well 
as additionally lower demand. 
The rules for the stage overlay (industry overlay) were defined as a combination of sectors with a high risk profile 
(according to industry strategy) or medium risk profile and a hold/decrease strategy as well as a threshold value of 
250 base points with the one-year default probabilities according to UGB/IFRS.  
The measurement of the credit risk for the effects of climate change is done firstly via the LGD models, whereby the 
climate risk is reflected indirectly via the collateral value and secondly ESG factors are taken into account in the 
valuation of the soft facts in the company rating models. As of 31 December 2024, in addition, no collective 
assessment of the significant increase in the credit risk (stage overlays) is deemed to be necessary.

Financial position and net assets  
Financial position 
Liquidity was in line with the provisions of Articles 411 et seq. of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 (CRR) and Commission 
Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/61 of 10 October 2014. The reason for the constant overfulfilment of the strict 
regulatory specifications are the primary deposits which are developing pleasingly based on the strong customer 
relationships and the investment in high-quality securities and Central Bank deposits that serve as liquidity buffer. In 
addition to a balanced ratio between customer deposits and customer receivables, a good structural refinancing 
structure between banks is the focus of the liquidity management. 
 
Net assets 
The net asset position of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group continued to improve. 
The own funds of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group amount to EUR 3,357.1 million. The own funds comprise Tier 
1 and Tier 2 capital. 
Tier 1 capital (CET 1) is EUR 3,343.8 million and the Additional Tier 1 capital (AT 1) is EUR 0.0 million. Tier 2 capital 
(T2) amounts to EUR 13.3 million. 
The Tier 1 capital ratio is 27.5% (24.4%), again way above the minimum requirements. 
Report on branches  
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has a total of 195 branches and regional consultation centres (without self-
service locations), of which 119 are in Styria, 1 in Vienna, 39 in Bosnia and 36 in North Macedonia. In addition, there 
are 36 self-service locations in Styria. 
As of the year-end, 2,610 (2,614) bank operations staff were employed in the branches and regional consultation 
centres of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group (less leased staff).

General information 
Steiermärkische Bank und Sparkassen AG (Steiermärkische Sparkasse) was founded in 1825 and is the oldest savings 
bank in Styria. Its registered office is at Sparkassenplatz 4, 8010 Graz, Austria. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group 
offers a full range of banking and financial services such as savings, asset management (among others, investment 
fund business), loans, mortgages, securities trading and derivatives business, securities management, project 
financing, export financing, corporate financing, capital and money market services, foreign exchange and currencies 
trading and leasing. Geographically, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group offers its services, in addition to in Styria, 
also in Slovenia, Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and North Macedonia. 
Steiermärkische Verwaltungssparkasse holds a stake of 73,8 % in Steiermärkische Sparkasse as at the end of 2024. 
The business purpose of Steiermärkische Verwaltungssparkasse is the management of its own assets, which is 
essentially its holding in Steiermärkische Sparkasse. Steiermärkische Verwaltungssparkasse is committed to the 
common good as outlined in its Articles of Association. Taking this into account, substantial funds were again provided 
in 2024 in particular to promote youth and science as well as for social, cultural and sporting purposes. 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse is a member in the joint liability scheme (HV) pursuant to Art. 4 Para. 1 Clause 127 CRR 
and the institute-related protection system (IPS) approved by the supervisory authority pursuant to Art. 113 Para. 7 
CRR. As of the reference date for the statement of financial position, in addition to Erste Group Bank AG and Erste 
Bank der österreichischen Sparkassen AG, Bausparkasse der österreichischen Sparkassen AG and all Austrian 
Sparkassen belong to the IPS and the HV. According to the provisions regarding the joint liability scheme, the joint 
fulfilment of the liabilities towards customers (this relates to all deposits pursuant to Section 1 Para. 1 Clause 1 of the 
Austrian Banking Act (BWG), all monetary deposits based on balances from bank transactions, all monetary 
receivables from the issuing of securities, except own fund components pursuant to Art. 26 et seq.,, 51 et seq., 62 et 
seq., CRR and receivables from transactions relevant under criminal law) is given dependent on the respective 
capitalisation of the individual HV members. 
The individual payments of the members to be provided taking into account the regulatory requirements and general 
upper limits exist in support measures (such as the granting of liquidity aids, granting of loans, adoption of guarantees, 
supply of equity) and after performance of the statutory deposit protection in the fulfilment of the customer 
receivables protected pursuant to the HV/IPS contract in the event of a member becoming bankrupt. Based on the 
statutory requirements and those under supervisory law, the upper limits for support measures of the individual 
measures were increased and an ex-ante fund (IPS fund) was set up. Payments are made into the ex-ante fund on a 
quarterly basis.  
The members of the joint liability scheme / IPS form, with Erste Group Bank AG, a banking group pursuant to Section 
30 of the Banking Act (BWG) or a consolidated group under supervisory law pursuant to Art. 18 and Art. 19 CRR 
whose higher-level bank is Erste Group Bank AG. This requires that Erste Group Bank AG carries out the consolidated 
own funds and the consolidated own fund requirements on the basis of the consolidation under supervisory law. For 
the purpose of inclusion of the members of the joint liability scheme in the consolidated annual financial statements 
of Erste Group Bank AG, a reporting package drawn up pursuant to the International Financing Reporting Standards 
(IFRS), as they are to be applied in the EU, is sent to Erste Group Bank AG. 
As securities of Steiermärkische Sparkasse are admitted to trading on a regulated market (Vienna Stock Exchange), 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse is required to prepare consolidated financial statements in accordance with section 245(3) 
UGB. On the basis of the EU regulation on the application of international accounting standards (1606/2002/EC), 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse is required to prepare its consolidated financial statements in accordance with the 
International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). 
Financial Reporting (FINREP) and Common Reporting (COREP) were introduced by the European Banking Authority 
(EBA) in 2014 and represent a mandatory regulatory framework to be adopted by credit institutions based in the EU.

b)     Currency conversion 
The consolidated annual financial statements of Steiermärkische Sparkasse are prepared in euros, the functional 
currency of Steiermärkische Sparkasse, the parent company of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. Functional 
currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which the company operates. Each company within 
the Group stipulates its own functional currency. The items contained in the financial statements of the respective 
Group company are valued using this functional currency. 
The conversion rates of the central banks of the respective countries are used for currency conversion. The central 
rates of the European Central Bank are used for Group companies whose functional currency is the euro. 
i. Transactions and balances in foreign currency 
Foreign currency transactions are initially converted by the Group companies into the functional currency at the 
exchange rate valid at the date of the transaction. In the following, monetary assets and debts in a foreign currency 
are converted into the functional currency on any reference date, using the reference date exchange rate. All resulting 
conversion differences are indicated in the income statement under the item "Trading result". Non-monetary items 
that are rated at historical acquisition or production costs in a foreign currency are converted with the historic rate on 
the date of the business transaction, i.e. there are no conversion differences that result from them. Non-monetary

rate as at the date of fair value measurement, with the result that the translation differences are part of the fair value

ii. Conversion of the financial statements of companies incorporated into the consolidated annual 
financial statements 
The assets and debts of the foreign business operations (foreign subsidiaries and branches) are converted with the 
exchange rate on the statement of financial position reference date (reference date exchange rate) into the reporting 
currency of Steiermärkische Sparkasse (euros). Items in the consolidated income statement and consolidated 
statement of comprehensive income are translated into euro using the average exchange rate for the respective 
reporting period, which is calculated on the basis of daily exchange rates. Goodwill resulting in connection with the 
acquisition of a foreign subsidiary, intangible assets such as customer base and brand as well as adjustments of the 
carrying values of assets and debts to the fair value are treated as assets and debts of this foreign subsidiary and 
converted with the reference date exchange rate.  
Exchange rate differences that arise from the conversion are recorded in the item "Currency reserve" in the 
consolidated statement of income and costs. The cumulative result is shown in the item "Currency reserve" in the 
consolidated statement of recognised income and expenses. When a foreign subsidiary is disposed of, the cumulative 
conversion differences that have been recorded up until that point in the other result are taken into account in the 
income statement in the item "Other operating income".

Standards and interpretations not yet effective 
The standards, amendments and interpretations below have been adopted and published by the IASB but are not yet 
effective. The Amendments of IAS 21 been adopted by the EU. 
IFRS 18 presentation and information in the financial statements. IFRS 18 was published by the IASB in April 2024 
and is effective for fiscal years beginning on or after 1 January 2027. The standard replaces IAS 1. The goal of IFRS 
18 consists of defining requirements of the presentation and disclosure of information in financial statements for 
general purposes in order to ensure that they provide relevant information that faithfully presents the assets, liabilities, 
equity, income and expenses of a company. 
The application of IFRS 18 will lead to adjustments in the structure of the consolidated income statement of the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group that are caused by a new obligatory interim total “operating profit or loss”. In 
addition, new disclosures in the area of key performance indicators defined by the management will be provided. 
Amendments to IAS 21: Effects of changes in exchange rates - lack of convertibility. The amendments to IAS 21 
were published in August 2023 and are effective for fiscal years beginning on or after 1 January 2025. The 
amendments include guidelines specifying when a currency can be converted and how the exchange rate is to be 
determined if it is not. No fundamental effects on the consolidated annual financial statements of the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group are expected from the application of these amendments. 
Amendments to IFRS 9 and IFRS 7: Amendments to the classification and valuation of financial instruments. The 
amendments to IFRS 9 and IFRS 7 were published in May 2024 and are effective for fiscal years beginning on or after 
1 January 2026. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group intends to apply these changes early in 2025. 
The changes of IFRS 9 make it possible for a company to view a financial liability that is settled via an electronic 
payment system as settled before the date of fulfilment. In addition, they include clarifications for the classification of 
financial assets in the areas: contractual conditions that are in line with an elementary loan agreement, financial assets 
that are not eligible for recourse and contractually linked instruments. The changes of IFRS 7 bring new disclosure 
obligations for investments in equity instruments that are valued at the fair value without impact on income, and for 
contractual conditions that can change the point in time or the amount of the contractual cashflows. 
The changes to IFRS 9 will lead to a different SPPI valuation of financial assets whose interest rates will be adjusted 
based on the fulfilment of certain ESG-based goals by the debtors. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group will no 
longer assess them according to whether the effects of adjustments are minor but whether the adjusted cashflows 
could deviate materially from the contractual cashflows without such a contingent function. It is not expected that the 
new assessment will change the valuation of the financial assets concerned. The other changes to IFRS 9 are not 
expected to have any significant effects on the consolidated financial statements of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
Group. Changes to IFRS 7 will lead to new disclosures. 
Annual improvements, volume 11 In July 2024, the IASB adopted and published a number of various amendments 
to existing standards. The amendments to IFRS 1, IFRS 7, IFRS 9, IFRS 10 and IAS 7 are to be applied for fiscal years 
beginning on or after 1 January 2026. The adoption of these amendments is not expected to have a significant effect 
on the consolidated financial statements of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group.

1. Segment reporting 
The external segment reporting is oriented to the internal reporting and reflects the decision-making and responsibility 
structure of the management (management approach pursuant to IFRS 8 Business segments). 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has the following four segments that require reporting:  
 Regions 
 Commercial 
 International Business 
 Residual activities 
The Regions segment incorporates the result of the business relationships with private customers in Styria and in 
Vienna as well as business relationships with commercial small and medium-sized enterprises in Styria, with the 
exception of Graz. 
The Commercial segment incorporates the business relationships with small and medium-sized enterprises in Graz 
and Vienna and with centrally supported commercial large companies and project financing and cooperative housing. 
In addition, the results from participations in financial institutions in Austria are assigned to this segment.  
The International Business segment essentially includes the results from the equity investments in banking and 
financial institutions in Southeast Europe. Steiermärkische Sparkasse has a stake in the following foreign banks: Erste 
& Steiermärkische Bank in Croatia, Sparkasse Bank in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Erste Bank Novi Sad in Serbia, Banka 
Sparkasse in Slovenia and Sparkasse Bank Skopje in North Macedonia. Steiermärkische Sparkasse also has a stake in 
financial institutions in Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and North Macedonia.  
The following geographical sub-segments are differentiated for the segment International business: 
 Bosnia and Herzegovina 
 North Macedonia 
 Croatia 
 Serbia 
 Slovenia 
 Other international business 
Each geographical sub-segment includes the stakes in the banking and financial institutions of the respective country. 
The “Other International Business” sub-segment includes other financing in Southeast Europe and the operating 
expenses for the management of the equity investments. 
The Residual activities segment incorporates the results from financial instruments, the statement of financial position 
structure result, one-off effects that cannot be assigned to any segment to uphold comparability as well as the free 
capital (defined as the difference between the average IFRS capital and the average economic capital assigned to the 
segments).  
The following are assigned to the individual segments accordingly: refinancing costs of the participations, interest in 
connection with non-performing loans and the costs for the funds for deposit protection and reconciliation.  
Equity is allocated on the basis of an economic approach which is used for the internal control of the business divisions. 
Equity is allocated for operational risk through operating costs and for credit risk through risk-weighted assets, for 
which a required rate of 12 % was applied. The market risk was also included in the capital allocation.

2. Interest surplus 
The interest surplus is broken down into interest income, other similar income, income costs and other similar costs. 
The decisive factor for the allocation to these items is whether the effective interest method is mandatorily to be 
applied for the recording of interest income and expenses pursuant to IFRS 9. 
"Interest income" relates to income from interest from financial assets at amortised cost and of financial assets rated 
at the fair value with no impact on profit or loss. They are recorded using the effective interest method, as described 
in the chapter "Financial instruments - Fundamental accounting principles". 
The item "Other similar income" includes interest-like income that result from non-derivative financial assets that are 
valued at fair value with an impact on income or loss, derivatives held for trading purposes, hedge accounting 
derivatives, receivables from financing leasing and negative interest from financial liabilities. The negative interest 
from financial liabilities also includes fees that are charged on deposits by business customers on the basis of a certain 
percentage of the outstanding balances. 
The item "Interest expenses" relates to interest expenses from financial liabilities valued at amortised cost and which 
are calculated using the effective interest method. This is described in the chapter "Financial instruments - 
Fundamental accounting principles”. 
The item "Other similar expenses” includes interest-like expenses that result from non-derivative financial liabilities 
that are valued at fair value with an impact on income or loss, derivatives held for trading purposes, hedge accounting 
derivatives, negative interest from financial assets, leasing liabilities, IFRS 9 and IAS 37 provisions (consideration of 
the fair value of the money through mere expiry) as well as net obligations from pension plans according to IAS 19 
(net interest costs on severance, pension and anniversary provisions). 
Interest income and other similar income include interest income from loans and advances to banks and customers, 
from cash in hand and balances as well as from bonds of all valuation categories of financial assets, from trade 
receivables and other receivables and from receivables from financing leasing. Interest expenses and other similar 
expenses include, in addition to interest expenses for deposits of banks and customers, also interest expenses for 
issued bonds and for other financial liabilities of all valuation categories and interest expenses from leasing obligations. 
In addition, the interest surplus includes interest from derivative financial instruments. 
In addition, modification gains and losses from financial assets in Stage 1 are indicated in the interest income. 
Furthermore, the not yet amortised amount of the origination fees/transaction costs that were included in the effective 
interest rate is recognised in interest income on the derecognition of assets in Stages 1 and 2 on the date of 
derecognition.

3.  Net fee and commission income 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group receives fee and commission income from various services that it performs for 
customers. Commission income is measured on the basis of the consideration specified in the contract with the 
customer. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse records this income if it transfers a promised service to individual customers.  
Commissions from the provision of services over a certain period of time are assigned to the corresponding period of 
time. This includes commissions from credit commitments, liability commissions and other commissions from the 
credit business, commission income from the asset management, the custodian business and other management and 
consulting fees as well as fees from the insurance brokerage business and the building society brokerage business. 
The payments that are made over a certain period of time also include payment transaction services such as periodic 
card fees. 
Commission income from the implementation of transaction-related services for third parties, such as the acquisition 
and sale of shares or other securities for customers or foreign exchange transactions as well as brokerage 
commissions from services such as the sale of fund or insurance products will be recorded after the completion of the 
respective transaction. The transaction-based payments also include payment transaction services such as 
withdrawal fees. 
A contract with a customer that results in the recognition of a financial instrument can be partially within the scope of 
IFRS 9 and partially within the scope of IFRS 15. In such a case, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group first applies 
IFRS 9 for the separation and measurement of the contractual components within the scope of IFRS 9 and only then 
applies IFRS 15 to the remaining contractual components. For instance, administrative fees agreed in a loan agreement 
that are not an integral part of the effective interest of a financial instrument are taken into account in the commission 
surplus.

Balance sheet accounting and valuation methods for financial instruments 
A financial instrument is any contract that gives rise to a financial asset of one entity and a financial liability or equity 
instrument of another entity. Pursuant to IFRS 9, all financial assets and liabilities which also include financial 
instruments are to be recognised in the statement of financial position and valued depending on the category assigned 
to them. 
Purchases or sales of a financial asset that are usual on the market are recorded on the fulfilment reference date. The 
settlement date is the date at which a financial asset is transferred. 
The two following valuation methods are fundamentally available for the valuation of financial instruments: amortised 
costs and fair value. 
i. Amortised costs and effective rate of interest 
Amortised costs are the amount with which the financial asset or the financial liability is rated during first-time 
recognition, less the repayments, plus or less the cumulative amortisation of any difference between the original 
amount and the amount repayable on the due date, using the effective interest method and in the case of financial 
assets after consideration of any loss allowance. 
The effective interest rate (EIR) is the interest rate with which the estimated future incoming/outgoing payments are 
discounted over the expected term of the financial asset or the financial liability exactly to the gross carrying amount 
of a financial asset (i.e. the amortised costs before consideration of loss allowances) or to the amortised costs of a 
financial liability. In the process, the estimated cashflows consider all contractual conditions of the financial instrument; 
however, expected credit losses are not taken into consideration. The calculation also incorporates transaction costs 
and processing fees if these are an integral part of the EIR and all other premiums and discounts on the nominal 
amount. 
ii. Fair value 
Details on methods that are applied for the fair value measurement and on the fair value hierarchy are shown in Note 
23 Fair value of financial instruments. 
Classification and subsequent measurement of financial assets  
The classification and subsequent measurement of financial assets under IFRS 9 is dependent on the two following 
criteria: 
 the business model for the control of financial assets; and 
 the characteristics of the contractual cashflow of the financial asset.  
 
Further details are shown in this chapter under “Material discretionary decisions, assumptions and estimates”. 
The application of these criteria leads to the classification of financial assets in three valuation categories that are 
described in the respective note. 
 Financial assets valued at amortised cost (AC) 
 Financial assets measured at fair value without impact on profit or loss (FVOCI instruments) 
 Financial assets at fair value through profit or loss (FVPL) 
Classification and subsequent measurement of financial liabilities 
With the exception of the financial liabilities rated at the fair value through profit or loss, financial liabilities are valued 
at amortised costs. Interest expenses are calculated by applying the effective interest rate to the amortised cost of a 
financial liability. For further details on financial liabilities, we refer to Note 18 Financial liabilities valued at amortised 
costs.

Impairments of financial instruments 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group records impairments in its financial assets from debt instruments that are not 
valued at the FVPL, its leasing receivables and its off-balance-sheet credit risks from financial guarantees and certain 
credit commitments. 
The expected credit loss (ECL) is recognised as an impairment. For the measurement of the amount of the expected 
credit losses and the recording of interest income, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group differentiates the impairment 
stages: 
Stage 1 relates to financial instruments, for which no significant increase in credit risk has been identified since initial 
recognition. The impairment is calculated in the amount of the share of the credit losses expected over the overall 
term that result from possible defaults during the next 12 months. Interest income is recorded applying the EIR to the 
gross carrying amount of the financial asset. 
Financial instruments in Stage 2 indicate a significant increase in the default risk since the initial recognition. The 
impairment is calculated at an amount equal to the lifetime expected credit losses. Interest income is recorded applying 
the EIR to the gross carrying amount of the financial asset (as in Stage 1). When committed credit facilities are used 
by customers that have not defaulted, the entire (statement of financial position and off-balance-sheet) credit risk 
volume is classified as Stage 1 or Stage 2, depending on the development of the credit risk between commitment and 
first-time use. 
Financial instruments in Stage 3 have an impaired credit rating. Here, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has 
chosen the approach to align the IFRS 9 definition of the “impaired credit rating” to the default definition under 
supervisory law pursuant to the specifications of the European Banking Authority in EBA/GL/2016/07 and the 
Delegated Regulation (EU) 2018/171 of the Commission. When the definition of default is used, there is generally an 
overall customer perspective at the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group that results in an assignment to Stage 3 with 
all transactions with a customer, also if the default is only done in one of several transactions (pulling effect). However, 
an upgrade of the default status brings about a loss of the impaired credit standing in all risk positions with the 
customer. The impairment of the financial instruments in Stage 3 is calculated at an amount equal to the lifetime 
expected credit losses. Interest income is calculated applying the effective interest rate to the amortised costs of the 
financial asset (i.e. the net carrying value). From a statement of financial position perspective, interest deferrals and 
accruals are recorded on the basis of the gross carrying amount of the financial asset. The difference between the 
accrued or deferred interest income is compensated by the statement of financial position loss allowance account 
(without influencing the impairment in the income statement). 
For purchased or originated credit-impaired financial assets (POCI), lifetime expected credit losses are initially included 
in the credit-adjusted effective interest rate. Therefore, no loss allowance will be formed at the beginning. 
Subsequently, only disadvantageous changes of the credit losses expected over the term are taken into consideration 
after the first-time recording as an impairment, whereas positive changes are recorded as impairment income that 
increase the gross carrying value of the POCI assets. No impairment stages are differentiated for POCI assets. 
The valuation of the expected credit losses includes cashflows that are expected from collateral and the financial 
guarantees held by the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group that are seen as an integral contractual component of the 
financial assets whose risk is guaranteed. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group views guarantees as integral when 
they are concluded as of or close to the start of the guaranteed financial assets. If the bank is granted the option of 
requiring a guarantee in a loan agreement, this guarantee is also considered integral. Bonuses that are paid for an 
integral financial guarantee and other loan collateral are included in the effective interest rate of the underlying 
financial asset. 
More detailed information on the identification of significant increases in credit risk (including assessment on a 
collective basis), on estimation methods for the calculation of 12-month ECL and lifetime expected credit losses, and 
on the definition of default is presented in the “Credit risk” section of note 31. Reviewing and monitoring of the credit 
risk shown Information on the definition of default are included in Note 34 Calculation of the expected credit loss.

Derecognition of financial instruments and treatment of contractual modifications 
i. Derecognition of financial assets 
In the income statement, the difference between the carrying amount of the derecognised financial asset and the 
consideration received is shown in the line "Gains/Losses from the derecognition of financial assets at amortised 
costs" or, in the case of financial assets at the FVOCI in the line "Other gains/losses from the derecognition of financial 
instruments measured at fair value without impact on profit or loss. For financial assets at the FVPL, the gains or losses 
from the derecognition together with the valuation results are recorded in the line "Trading result" or "Gains/Losses 
from financial instruments measured at fair value through profit or loss". 
ii. Derecognition criteria for contractual modifications of financial assets 
Within the framework of the ongoing credit business and in agreement with the respective debtors, it may be the case 
that the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group re-negotiates certain conditions of the underlying contracts or amends 
them in another way. This can include, for instance, market-driven commercial re-negotiations or contractual 
amendments that aim to mitigate or prevent financial difficulties of the borrower. For the assessment of the economic 
assets and the financial effects of such contractual modifications, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has 
developed a number of criteria based on which it is determined whether the amended criteria fundamentally differ 
from the original ones and therefore the financial asset needs to be derecognised. 
Market-based interest adjustments that meet specific conditions do not trigger any assessment of the significance of 
the change: Instead, they result in a new calculation of the EIR of the loans. Such interest adjustments usually do not 
refer to non-performing loans that do not have any forbearance status and for which an early payment option and a 
sufficiently competitive refinancing market exist. In addition, the costs that are incurred by the debtor in the case of 
advance payment or early termination must be assessed as low. Such conditions introduce an implicit, variable interest 
element in the contract. This type of interest adjustments is rarely used for loans in Stage 2. 
Fundamental amendments result in the derecognition of the original financial asset and the first-time recognition of 
the modified financial asset as a new financial instrument. The following events are covered by this regulation: 
 change of contractual counterparty (unless a formal change, e.g. change of legal designation); 
 change of contract currency (unless the change results from the exercise of an option to change currency contained 
in the original contract with pre-defined conditions or the new currency is pegged to the original currency); 
introduction of contractual clauses that do not meet the SPPI criterion (unless concessions that improve the 
collectibility of receivables by allowing obligors to recover from financial difficulties); or 
 removal of a contractual clause that does not meet the SPPI criterion. 
 the removal of a contractual clause that is not compliant with SPPI 
For certain derecognition criteria, it is decisive whether the contractual modification was carried out at a debtor with 
financial difficulties. Certain contractual modifications at debtors with financial difficulties are not seen as fundamental 
as they aim to improve the prospects of the bank regarding the retrievability of the receivables by the repayment plans 
being adapted to the specific financial prerequisites of these debtors. However, if such contractual modifications are
