applied to debtors who are not non-performing, these can be seen as fundamental enough in order to trigger a 
derecognition. This is explained in more detail below. 
The following criteria lead to derecognition unless they are deemed to be forbearance methods, they are applied to 
defaulted customers or they trigger a default (i.e. the derecognition is based on a modification that does not result 
from financial difficulties of the customer): 
 change in the repayment schedule that results in the weighted remaining term of the asset changing by more than 
100% and not less than two years compared to the original asset;  
 change in the timing/amount of contractual cash flows that results in the present value of the modified cash flows 
(discounted by the effective interest rate before modification) deviating by more than 10% from the gross carrying 
amount of the asset directly before the change (cumulative assessment taking all changes in the last twelve months 
into account); or 
 conversion of a variable interest rate into a fixed interest rate or conversely for the entire residual term of the financial 
asset. 
If contractual modifications that are deemed to be forbearance measures or that are applied to defaulted customers 
or that trigger a default (i.e. they result from financial difficulties of the customer) are so fundamental that they are 
seen qualitatively as repayment of the original contract, they result in derecognition. Examples of such modifications 
are: 
 a new agreement with fundamentally amended contractual components that was signed within the framework of a 
restructuring that has become necessary after a standstill agreement that suspends the rights of the original assets 
temporarily; 
 merger of several original loans into one asset with fundamentally amended conditions; or 
 conversion of a revolving loan into a non-revolving loan. 
Contractual modifications that lead to a derecognition of the respective original asset lead to the first-time recognition 
of a new financial asset. If the debtor has defaulted or the fundamental modification leads to the default, the new 
asset will be treated as a POCI. The difference between the carrying amount of the derecognised asset and the fair 
value of the new POCI asset with first-time recognition is indicated in the income statement in the line "Result from 
impairments of financial instruments". 
If the obligor is not in default or the material modification does not result in default, the new asset recognised after 
derecognition of the original asset is allocated to Stage 1. For loans at amortised cost, the non-amortised amount of 
the origination fees/transaction costs, which is accounted for in the effective interest rate, is included in “Net interest 
income” as at the date of derecognition. The reversal of impairments that were formed for the original asset at the 
time of the fundamental modification and the formation of the impairment for the new asset are indicated in the line 
"Result from impairments of financial instruments". The remaining difference is shown in the line "Gains/Losses from 
the derecognition of financial assets valued at amortised costs". 
For debt instruments not measured at FVPL and subject to contractual modifications that do not result in derecognition, 
the gross carrying amount of the asset is adjusted by the recognition of a modification gain or loss. This modification 
gain or loss equals the difference between the gross carrying amount before modification and the present value of 
the cash flows of the modified asset, discounted by the original effective interest rate. In the income statement, the 
modification gain or loss is shown in the line "Interest income" under "interest surplus" when the modifications refer 
to financial assets in Stage 1. For financial assets in Stage 2 and 3 and POCI assets, the modification gain or loss is 
reported in “Net income from impairment on financial instruments”. However, if the contractual modification entails 
the bank surrendering its rights to cash flows in connection with the outstanding amount of the asset, such as (partial) 
waiver of the principal or accrued interest, this waiver is treated as a write-down. 
iii. Depreciation 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group writes down a financial asset or part thereof when it has no realistic 
expectations of receiving the respective cash flows from the asset. With such a depreciation, the gross carrying 
amount of the asset and the respective status of impairments are reduced in equal measure.

credit business. Write-downs can result from forbearance measures in which the bank contractually waives a part of 
the outstanding amount in order to help the customer in overcoming financial difficulties and thus to improve the 
prospects of the retrievability of the remaining credit (in the case of corporate customers normally assuming a going 
concern). Information on forbearance is included in Note 36 Restructurings, renegotiations and forbearance.  
In scenarios without a going concern, write-downs of irretrievable receivables from corporate customers through legal 
enforcement measures such as bankruptcy, liquidation or court proceedings. Other triggers for write-downs can result 
from decisions to waive enforcement due to the worthlessness of the receivable or collateral, or generally from the 
assessment that the receivable is economically lost. For retail customers, the uncollectibility and the timing and 
amount of the write-down are revealed in the course of the collection process when it becomes apparent that the 
amount due cannot be collected, for example as a result of ongoing insolvency proceedings. Other irretrievable 
receivables are written off after the collection process. 
iv. Derecognition of financial liabilities 
In the income statement, the difference between the carrying amount of the derecognised financial liability and the 
paid consideration depending on the derecognised financial liability is indicated in the line "Other gains/losses from 
the derecognition of financial instruments measured at fair value without impact on profit or loss", "Gains/losses from 
financial instruments measured at fair value through profit or loss" or "Trading result". 
Fundamental discretionary decisions, assumptions and estimates 
i. SPPI assessment 
The assessment of whether contractual cash flows from financial assets are solely payments of principal and interest 
(SPPI) is subject to significant judgements on the basis of IFRS 9. This judgement is critical to the IFRS 9 classification 
and measurement process, as it determines whether the asset is to be measured at FVPL or, depending on the 
assessment of the business model, at amortised cost or FVOCI. Taking into account the contractual characteristics of 
loans in the business of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, discretionary decisions are taken primarily in the 
following areas: Compensation for early repayment, project financing and benchmark tests for loans that are endowed 
with incongruent interest components. 
The assessment whether compensation for early repayment that is applied to loans constituted an appropriate 
compensation for early termination or advance payment is based on a comparison of the amount of the fees with the 
economic costs that have been incurred by the bank as a result of the early termination or advance payment. For this 
purpose, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses a quantitative test, in which these costs are calculated from the 
loss of the interest margin and the interest loss resulting from a potential reduction in the interest rate level before the 
advance payment. The appropriateness of the fees can also be presented on a qualitative basis, such as on the basis 
of common market practice regarding the size of prepayment penalties and their acceptance by authorities. 
With project financing, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group checks whether it involves an elementary loan 
agreement and not an investment in the financed projects. In this context, credit rating, degree of collateralisation, 
existing guarantees of the sponsors and the equity endowment of the financed projects are taken into account. 
Incongruent interest components refer to variable-interest financial assets for which: - the term of the reference 
interest rate (e.g. EURIBOR) deviates from the frequency of the fixed-interest term ("tenor mismatch"), -  time delays 
occur when the interest rate is fixed before the start of the interest period, or such characteristics are combined. In 
order to subject such incongruent interest components to an SPPI assessment, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, 
has developed a so-called benchmark test. This test checks whether the mismatched interest components could 
result in (undiscounted) contractual cash flows that differ considerably from a benchmark deal which does not indicate 
such mismatches. For assets with interest rate mismatches resulting only from time-delayed interest rates (i.e. without 
tenor mismatches), the SPPI criterion is deemed fulfilled based on a qualitative assessment if the time between the 
fixing of the interest rate and the beginning of the interest period is not more than one month.

63
The implementation of the quantitative benchmark test was relevant in particular in the transition to IFRS 9 as at 1 
January 2018 for the portfolio existing at this point in time. Subsequently, the issuing of new loans with interest 
incongruencies was largely restricted so that a quantitative benchmark test is only applied in exceptional cases. 
ii. Assessment of the business model 
With each financial asset that is compliant with SPPI, it needs to be assessed during first-time recognition whether 
this is held in a business model whose goal is only to collect the contractual cashflows (business model "hold") or in 
the collection of the contractual cashflows and the sale of the assets (business model "hold and sell") or whether this 
is held in another business model. The decisive aspect for making the distinction is therefore the frequency and 
materiality of sales of assets in the respective business model. As an asset is allocated to a business model on initial 
recognition, it is possible that cash flows in subsequent periods are realised differently than originally expected, so 
that a different measurement method appears appropriate. Pursuant to IFRS 9, such retrospective changes to existing 
financial assets usually do not lead to reclassifications or error corrections in previous periods. However, the new 
information on how cash flows are realised can indicate that the business model and thus the measurement method 
for newly acquired or newly originated financial assets has changed. 
At the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, certain sales and other derecognitions are not seen as being in conflict with 
a business model with the goal of collecting contractual cashflows. Examples are sales due to an increase in the 
default risk, sales that take place close to the due date of the asset, as well as rare sales due to non-recurring events 
(such as changes in the regulatory or fiscal environment, major internal restructurings or company mergers or a serious 
liquidity crisis) or a derecognition that results from an offer by the issuer to exchange a bond. Other types of sales 
that are carried out in the business model "Hold" are assessed retrospectively. If certain quantitative threshold values 
are exceeded during this process or if this is seen as necessary with regard to new expectation, the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group will also conduct a prospective test. If the carrying amount of assets that are expected to be sold 
from the current business model over their expected useful life for reasons other than those named above exceeds 
10% of the carrying amount of the portfolio, new acquisitions or originations of assets must be allocated to a different 
business model. 
iii. Impairments of financial instruments 
The impairment model of expected credit losses per se is based on discretionary decisions as it requires an 
assessment whether a significant increase in the default risk exists, without providing detailed guidelines on this. With 
regard to the significant increase in the default risk, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has stipulated specific 
assessment criteria that consist of qualitative information and quantitative threshold values. Another complex area is 
the formation of groups of similar assets, which is necessary in order to assess the increase of credit risk on a 
collective basis before specific information is available at the level of individual instruments. The calculation of the 
expected credit losses incorporates complex models that are based on historical statistics on default probabilities and 
default loss ratios, their extrapolations in the case of insufficient observations, individual estimates of the credit 
standing-adapted cashflows and probabilities of various scenarios, including consideration of future-oriented 
information. In addition, the actually expected term of the instruments must be modelled with regard to revolving credit 
facilities. 
More detailed information on the identification of significant increases in credit risk (including assessment on a 
collective basis), on estimation methods for the calculation of 12-month ECL and lifetime expected credit losses, and 
on the definition of default is presented in the “Credit risk” section of note 31. Reviewing and monitoring of the credit 
risk shown Information on the definition of default are included in Note 34 Calculation of the expected credit loss. The 
development of the risk provisions is described in Note 36 Development of the loss allowances for credit risks.

19.  Financial assets measured at fair value without impact on profit or loss – Debt 
instruments 
Debt instruments are recognised in the statement of financial position at fair value through other comprehensive 
income (FVOCI) if its contractual cashflows are compliant with SPPI and they are held within a business model whose 
goals are both the collection of contractual cashflows as well as the sale of assets (business model "Hold and sell"). 
In the statement of financial position, they are included as “Debt instruments” under “Financial assets at fair value 
through other comprehensive income”. 
Interest income from these assets is calculated according to the effective interest method and indicated in the income 
statement in the line "Interest income" under "Interest surplus". impairment income and expenses are included in the 
line "Result from impairments of financial instruments". The corresponding charge is recognised in OCI and not against 
the carrying amount of the asset. The valuation effect in the income statement is thus the same as with financial 
assets valued at amortised costs. 
The difference between the fair value at which the assets are indicated in the statement of financial position and the 
amortised costs is shown in the statement of changes in equity in the item "Fair value reserve" as a cumulative other 
result (other comprehensive income, "OCI"). The changes in the reporting period are posted in the other result in the 
line "Fair value reserve of debt instruments".. This line also contains the corresponding charge for impairment gains 
or losses. On derecognition of the financial asset, the amount previously accumulated in other comprehensive income 
is reclassified to the income statement in “Other gains/losses arising from the derecognition of financial instruments 
not measured at fair value through profit or loss”. 
At the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, the FVOCI category investments in bonds, i.e. credit business, is not included 
in this valuation category. Similarly to the bonds valued at amortised costs, these refer to various business goals such 
as fulfilment of internal/external liquidity risk requirements and efficient placement of the structural liquidity surplus, 
strategic positions decided upon by the Management Board, initiation and promotion of customer relationships, 
replacement for credit transactions or other activities to increase income. The common feature of these debt 
instruments in the FVOCI category is that an active optimisation of income via sales makes a fundamental contribution 
to reaching the goals of this business model. The sales are made in order to optimise the liquidity situation or to 
generate gains and losses from changes in fair value. The business goals are accordingly achieved through the 
collection of contractual cashflows and through sales of the debt instruments.

The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group utilises the option to measure certain investments in equity instruments not 
held for trading at FVOCI. This right to choose is applied for participations that constitute strategically important 
business relationships in the banking sector (with the exception of the insurance business). The gains or losses from 
fair value changes for the reporting period are indicated as other result in the line "Fair value reserve of equity 
instruments" in the consolidated statements of recognised income and expenses. The cumulative gains or losses are 
indicated in the statement of changes in equity in the item "Fair value reserve". This amount recognised in OCI is never 
reclassified to the income statement. However, when such equity instruments are derecognised at FVOCI, the amount 
accumulated in OCI is reclassified to retained earnings. Dividends received from instruments of this category are 
indicated in the income statement in the line "Dividend income". In the statement of financial position, financial assets 
at fair value through other comprehensive income are reported as “Equity instruments” under “Financial assets at fair 
value through other comprehensive income”.

in the other result was EUR 166.5 million (2023: EUR 84.4 million).  
In 2024, no equity instruments were sold at FVOCI and there was thus no reclassification of the cumulative other

There are various reasons to measure debt instruments held at fair value through profit or loss (FVPL): 
FVPL valuations relate to debt instruments held that are assigned to other business models, i.e. they are not held 
either in a "Hold" business model or in a "Hold and sell" business model. In most cases, it is expected of these financial 
assets that they are sold before they become due, or that the development of the portfolio in which they are contained 
is assessed on the basis of the fair value. In the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, such business models are typical 
of assets that are held for trading purposes (i.e. financial assets that are held by the trading departments of the bank) 
or of assets whose value is predominantly realised by sales (e.g. credit syndications that have not yet been completed 
when the loan is offered for sale on the market. Furthermore, financial assets held by fully consolidated investment 
funds are measured at FVPL as they are managed and measured on a fair value basis. 
Other cases of FVPL valuations relate to financial assets whose contractual cashflows do not correspond to the SPPI 
criterion. In the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, certain debt instruments and loans to customers are affected by 
this. 
In the statement of financial position, held debt instruments measured at FVPL are shown as “Non-trading financial 
assets measured at fair value with impact on profit or loss” under the sub-items “Debt instruments” and “Loans and 
advances to customers”. Financial assets are indicated as "mandatory for the FvPL" when they are assigned to another 
business model (not "Hold" or "Hold and sell") and they are  not held for trading purposes or their contractual 
cashflows are not compliant with SPPI.  
Investments in equity instruments not held for trading are likewise measured at FVPL, unless they are designated as 
at FVOCI. In the statement of financial position, such instruments are reported as “Non-trading financial assets at fair 
value through profit or loss” in the sub-item “Equity instruments” or in the sub-category “Mandatorily measured at 
FVPL” in note 22. 
Pursuant to IFRS 9, all derivative financial instruments, if they are not designated as a collateral instrument, are 
classified as held for trading purposes and rated at fair value through profit or loss. For further statements, we refer 
to Note 21 “Derivatives”. 
In the income statement, gains and losses from non-derivative financial assets measured at FVPL are divided into 
interest and dividend income and gains and losses from changes in fair value. Interest income from debt instruments 
is shown in the line "Other similar income" under "Interest surplus" and calculated using the EIR on the amortised 
costs of the financial asset. Dividend income from equity instruments are shown in the line "Dividend income". The 
gains and losses from fair value changes are calculated after deduction of the interest or dividend income and include 
transaction costs and processing fees. They are shown in the line "Trading result" for financial assets held for trading 
purposes and in the line "Gains/losses from financial instruments measured at fair value through profit or loss, in the 
case of financial assets not held for trading purposes. For units in unconsolidated funds, the interest or dividend 
component is not separated from the gains and losses from changes in fair value.

21.  Derivatives  
To manage interest, currency and other market price risks, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses derivative 
financial instruments. Here, primarily interest rate swaps, interest rate options, currency swaps and currency options 
are used. 
For presentation purposes, the following derivatives are differentiated: 
 Derivatives – held for trading 
 Derivatives – Hedge accounting  
Derivatives are carried in the consolidated statement of financial position at their fair value (dirty price). Positive fair 
values of derivatives are indicated in the statement of financial position as assets, negative fair values as liabilities. 
Derivatives held for trading are derivatives not designated as a hedging instrument (hedge accounting). These are 
indicated irrespective of their internal classification, i.e. both derivatives of the trading book and derivatives of the 
non-trading book, in the item "Derivatives". 
“Derivatives – hedge accounting” are derivatives designated as a hedging instrument that meet the conditions of IAS 
39 (see hedge accounting). These are shown on the assets and liabilities side in the statement of financial position in 
the item "Derivatives – Hedge accounting". 
Changes in the fair value (clean price) of derivatives held for trading purposes are shown in the income statement in 
the "Trading result". Interest income/expenses of derivatives held for trading purposes and of hedging derivatives are 
shown in the income statement in the item "Other similar income" or "Other similar expenses" under "Interest surplus". 
These interest income/expenses are recognised on the basis of accrual similar to the effective interest rate with regard 
to the nominal value of the derivative, including the amortisation of the initial value (e.g. any advance fees). 
Embedded derivatives 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group issues certain financial liabilities that have structured features. “Structured 
features” means that a derivative is embedded in a non-derivative host instrument. 
Embedded derivatives that are separated are recognised in the statement of financial position as a stand-alone 
derivative and indicated in the statement of financial position in the item “Derivatives”.

23.  Fair value of financial instruments 
The fair value measurement in the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is done primarily on the basis of external data 
sources (stock exchange prices or broker listings in highly liquid market segments). Financial instruments whose fair 
value is measured on the basis of quoted market prices are mainly listed securities and derivatives, and liquid 
borrowings traded on over-the-counter markets. 
If the fair value of financial assets and financial liabilities recorded in the statement of financial position is not derived 
from an active market, it is determined using different valuation methods (including the use of mathematical methods). 
The inputs for these models are derived from observable market data as far as possible. If this is not possible, the fair 
value must be determined on the basis of estimates. The use of non-observable parameters is particularly relevant for 
models for the valuation of loans and equity instruments not listed on the stock exchange. Valuation models, the fair 
value hierarchy and fair values of financial instruments are explained in more detail below.  
A fair value is determined for all financial instruments on a recurring basis.  
Financial instruments recognised in the statement of financial position at fair value 
Description of the valuation models and parameters 
For the determination of the fair value of financial instruments, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses valuation 
models that have gone through an internal auditing process and for which the independent determination of the 
valuation parameters (such as interest rates, exchange rates, volatilities and credit spreads) is ensured.  
Loans  
The calculation method for the determination of the fair value of loans that do not meet the SPPI “solely payments of 
principal and interest”) criterion corresponds to the simple present value method according to the fair value definition. 
The loan risk is taken into account in that the contractually agreed cash flows are adapted with the inclusion of the 
probability of default (PD) and the Loss Given Default (LGD) in the expected cash flows. The discounting of the 
adjusted cash flows is done with an interest curve which comprises the risk-free interest rate and a refinancing 
supplement for priority non-collateralised issues. 
Debt instruments 
For plain vanilla debt securities (fixed and variable), the fair value is calculated by discounting future cash flows. The 
discounting curve is dependent on the interest rate of the issue currency and a spread adjustment derived from the 
issuer’s credit spread curve. If there is no issuer curve, the spread is derived from a similar instrument and adjusted 
for differences in the risk profile of the instrument. If no similar financial instrument is available, the spread is adjusted 
based on other information, e.g. credit spread calculation based on internal ratings and probabilities of default or on 
the basis of management decisions. In the case of more complex debt instruments (such as instruments with optional 
characteristics such as termination rights, interest upper and lower thresholds or index dependencies), the fair value 
is determined using a combination of discounted payment streams and more complex actuarial models like those that 
are also applied in the calculation method for OTC derivatives.  
Equity instruments 
For equity instruments not held for trading (participating interests) that do not have listed market prices on an active 
market, the fair value is determined through standard valuation methods using non-observable input parameters. 
These include the adjusted net inventory method, the simplified capitalised earnings method, the dividend discount 
model and the multiplier method.  
With the adjusted net inventory value method, the fair value of the assets and liabilities recorded in the statement of 
financial position of a company, as well as the fair value of assets and liabilities not recognised in the statement of 
financial position is determined as of the valuation reference date. The resulting fair values of the assets and liabilities 
recognised and not recognised in the statement of financial position therefore constitute the fair value of the equity 
of the associate company.

With the dividend discount model, it is assumed that the value of an equity instrument that is issued by a company 
corresponds to the present value of a perpetual dividend. The fair value is also calculated on the basis of discounted 
future income under the simplified income method. However, this method can also be used when only one income 
planned for a year is available. The simplified earnings value method and the dividend discount model discount future 
income and dividends, using a discounting interest rate that reflects the equity costs. The cost of equity is dependent 
on the risk-free interest rate, the market risk premium, the levered beta and the country risk premium. Levered beta is 
derived from the industry classification, which is published and managed by Prof. Damodaran.  
In rare cases, the multiplier method is used. This approach uses exchange rates and other relevant information from 
market transactions with comparable companies of an associate company to derive a multiplier. With the aid of this 
multiplier, the fair value of the participation value or goodwill is determined.  
OTC derivatives 
Derivatives that are traded on liquid markets (e.g. interest rate swaps and options, foreign currency transactions and 
options, options on listed securities or indices, credit default swaps and commodity swaps) are measured according 
to standard measurement models. These models incorporate discounted cashflow models, option models according 
to Black-Scholes and Hull-White as well as hazard rate models. The models are calibrated on listed market data 
(including implicit volatilities). Monte Carlo simulations are also used for the valuation of more complex instruments. 
For instruments in insufficiently liquid markets, market data from irregular transactions are used or extrapolation 
techniques used. For the determination of the fair value of derivatives secured in euros, a discount interest rate is used 
that reflects the interest rate fundamental for the interest of the cash collateral.  
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group values derivatives pursuant to the mid-market rate. In order to account for the 
level of the bid-ask spread of relevant items, an adjustment is made on the basis of market liquidity. The adjustment 
parameters depend on type of product, currency, duration and volume. The parameters are reviewed regularly and in 
the event of significant market movements.  
As part of the measurement of OTC derivatives, measurement adjustments are made for counterparty default risk 
(credit loss allowance (CVA)) and adjustments are made for own credit risk (debit loss allowance (DVA)). With the CVA, 
the adjustment is oriented to the expected positive risk of the derivative and the default probability of the counterparty. 
The DVA is determined by the expected negative exposure of the derivative and the default probability of the Erste 
Group. The modelling of the expected exposure is based on option replication strategies or Monte Carlo simulation 
techniques. 
The described methodology leads to CVA loss allowances in the amount of EUR -1.0 million (2023: EUR -1.0 million) 
and to DVA loss allowances in the total amount of EUR 0.2 million (2023: EUR 0.0 million). 
Based on an analysis carried out, it was decided that no funding loss allowance (FVA) will be considered for the 
valuation of OTC derivatives.

Validation and control 
The responsibility for the measurement of financial instruments at fair value is independent of the trading units. The 
valuation of financial instruments is done on the basis of a service level agreement in the Erste Group, where an 
independent validation department has been set up in order to ensure the functional separation between units for the 
model development, valuation price determination and validation. The aim of independent model validation is to 
measure model risks, which arise from the theoretical basis of the model, the quality of the input data (such as market 
data) and model calibration. 
Fair value hierarchy 
The fair values of financial assets and financial liabilities are assigned to the three categories of the IFRS fair value 
hierarchy. 
Level 1 of the fair value hierarchy 
Derivatives traded on the stock exchange (options), shares, sovereign bonds and other bonds as well as funds that 
are traded in liquid and active markets are assigned to this category. 
Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy 
If a market valuation is used whose market value cannot be seen as an active market due to reduced liquidity (derived 
from available market liquidity indicators), the underlying financial instrument is classified as Level 2. If no market 
prices are available, measurement will be done based on models drawn from market data. If all fundamental 
parameters of the valuation model are observable on the market, the financial instrument is classified as Level 2 of 
the fair value hierarchy. For Level 2 valuations, typically interest curves, credit spreads and implicit volatilities are used 
as transparent, observable market parameters.  
Besides OTC derivatives, this category primarily includes less liquid stocks, bonds and funds and own issues. 
Level 3 of the fair value hierarchy 
As soon as a parameter which is not observable on the market becomes significant for the measurement model or the 
market price is not regularly observable, the financial instrument is classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy. 
Typically, credit spreads that are derived from internal estimates for default probabilities (probability of default, PD) 
and loss ratios (loss given default, LGD) are used as non-observable parameters. 
The volume of financial instruments that are assigned to the Level 3 category can be divided into the following areas: 
 market values of derivatives for which the CVA adjustment has a fundamental influence on the valuation and are 
calculated by means of non-observable parameters (i.e. using internal estimates for PDs and LGDs). 
 Illiquid bonds and unlisted shares, shareholdings or funds measured using models that include values not observable 
on the market (e.g. credit spreads) or measured using broker quotations that are not attributable to Level 1 or Level 
2. 
 loans whose contractual payment streams of the assets do not only constitute payments of nominal and interest. 
The allocation of the corresponding levels is determined for all positions at the end of the reporting period.  
Financial assets are reclassified from Level 1 to Level 2 or 3 or vice versa when the above criteria for their allocation 
to the respective level cease to be met.

The fair value of loans and advances to customers and banks was calculated by discounting future cash flows while 
taking both interest rate and credit spread effects into account. The interest rate effect is based on market interest 
rate movements, while the changes in the credit spread are derived from probabilities of default (PDs) and losses 
given default (LGDs), which are used for internal risk calculations. Loans and advances were consolidated in 
homogeneous portfolios. The classification was based on rating methodology, rating category, maturity and the 
country in which they were posted. The fair values of bonds valued at amortised cost are primarily determined either 
directly by the market or on the basis of directly observable market parameters (e.g. interest rate curves).

actual interest environment and own credit spreads. For liabilities without contractual maturity (e.g. demand deposits), 
the residual carrying amount is assumed to be the minimum fair value.

The fair value of the securities and subordinate liabilities issued, measured at amortised cost is based on the same 
valuation models, as described above for the liabilities in the section “financial instruments recognised in the statement 
of financial position at fair value”. 
For off-balance-sheet liabilities (financial guarantees and irrevocable credit commitments) the fair value of irrevocable 
credit commitments is determined with the aid of regulatory credit conversion factors. The resulting credit equivalents 
are treated as assets recognised in the statement of financial position. The difference between the total fair value and 
the nominal value of the hypothetical credit risk equivalent corresponds to the fair value of the irrevocable credit 
commitments. If the total fair value of the hypothetical credit equivalents is higher than the nominal value, the fair 
value of irrevocable credit facilities is positive. The fair value of financial guarantees is calculated by analogy to a CDS 
model. In accordance with this model, the fair value results from the total of the present values of future cashflows. 
These include the outgoing payments as the result of the use of the guarantees which are modelled on the basis of 
the PDs and LGDs of the respective customers, as well as incoming payments from the guarantee fees received in 
future. If the present values of the future outgoing payments exceed the present values of the future guarantee fees, 
the fair value of financial guarantees is negative. 
24.  Hedge accounting 
To hedge the foreign currency and interest risk, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses hedge accounting. As 
permitted by the transitional provisions of IFRS 9, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group opted to continue applying 
the hedge accounting requirements of IAS 39. 
i. Fair value hedge 
Changes in the fair value (clean price) of derivative financial instruments that are used within the framework of qualified 
and designated fair value hedges are recorded in the income statement in the item “Trading result”. Interest income 
and expenses from hedging derivatives are indicated in the item "Other similar income" or "Other similar costs" under 
"Interest surplus". The fair value change in the underlying transaction that is assigned to the hedged risk is also 
recorded in the income statement in the item "Trading result" and is part of the carrying amount of the underlying 
transaction. 
For hedging relationships that have ended, the fair value adjustment of the underlying transaction is triggered over 
the residual term until the due date and indicated in the income statement in the item "Interest income" (when the 
underlying transaction was a financial asset) or "Interest costs" (if the underlying transaction was a financial liability) 
under "Interest surplus". For portfolio fair value hedges of interest change risks, the fair loss allowance of the 
terminated hedging relationship is amortised using the straight-line method and shown in the income statement in the 
item "Other similar income" under "Interest surplus". 
ii. Cash flow hedge 
Cash flow hedges are used to avoid uncertainty in future cash flows and thereby to stabilise net interest income. The 
effective part of the profit or loss of hedging instruments that are used within the framework of designated and 
qualified cashflow hedges is recorded in the other result in the "cashflow hedge provision". The ineffective portion is 
reported in the income statement under net trading income. The derivative is analysed at its clean price (i.e. without 
the interest component) to determine the effective/ineffective portion. If the hedged payment is incorporated into the 
income statement, the profits and losses from the hedging instrument are transferred from the other result into the 
corresponding item of the income statement (in most cases into the item "Other similar income" or "Other similar 
costs" under "Interest surplus"). There is no deviation in the accounting treatment for cash flow hedges compared to 
situations in which no hedge is applied. 
For hedging relationships that have ended, the cumulative gain or loss on the hedging instrument recognised in the 
other result remains in the “cashflow hedge reserve” until the transaction occurs. 
Hedging of interest risks  
The goals of the market risk management in the bank accounts of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group are the 
optimisation of the risk position taking into account the economic environment and the competition situation and in

compliance with the market value risk and the effect on the interest surplus as well as observance of an appropriate 
liquidity position for the Group.  
Pursuant to the goals of the risk management, the hedging activities are concentrated on the two main control 
parameters – the interest result on the one hand and the market value risk on the other. To manage these, the following 
instruments are available: Cashflow hedges are used for measures to stabilise the cashflows. Fair value hedges are 
used for measures to reduce the market value risk.  
Fair value hedges are used to turn fixed-interest or structured transactions into money-market linked transactions. 
Pursuant to the interest and hedge strategy, securitised liabilities of non-money-market linked issues are converted 
into such if necessary, using fair value hedges. Primarily interest swaps are used as instruments for these fair value 
hedges. To hedge the exchange rate risk, spot transactions, currency options, currency swaps, forward exchange 
transactions or statement of financial position items are used in a secured currency. 
If the market circumstances so necessitate, cashflow hedges are used to turn money-market linked transactions into 
fixed-interest transactions and thus to reduce the interest yield risk to guarantee minimum interest.

29.  Risk management 
Risk policy and strategy 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has developed forward-looking risk management guidelines geared to its 
business and risk profile. These rules are based on a clear risk strategy and define general principles, pursuant to 
which the entering into risks takes place across the entire group. The risk strategy of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
Group is in compliance with the business strategy and also takes into account the expected influence of external 
environmental factors on the planned business and risk developments.  
The risk strategy describes both the actual risk profile and the target risk profile, defines the risk management 
principles, the strategic goals as well as initiatives for the most important types of risk and sets strategic limits for the 
fundamental financial and non-financial types of risk that are listed in the risk materiality assessment. The risk strategy 
is implemented within the framework of a clearly defined governance structure. This serves to monitor the risk appetite, 
supplementary key performance ratios and to escalate the exceeding of limits. 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has chosen the Internet as a medium for the disclosure obligation pursuant to 
Article 434 of Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013 on prudential requirements for credit institutions and investment firms 
(Capital Requirements Regulation - CRR) in the European Union and Regulation (EU) No. 876/2019 amending 
Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013. Details can be found on the website of Steiermärkische Sparkasse at 
https://www.sparkasse.at/steiermaerkische/wir-ueber-uns/regulatorische-berichte 
Risk management organisation 
The risk monitoring and control is addressed by clear organisational structures with defined roles and responsibilities, 
delegated decision-making competence and risk limits. 
The Management Board and especially the Chief Risk Officer (CRO) of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group exercise 
their oversight functions within the framework of the risk management structure of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
Group. The risk control and management are perceived on the basis of the business strategy and the risk appetite 
approved by the Management Board. The CRO of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is responsible in collaboration 
with the Chief Risk Officer of the subsidiary banks for the implementation and compliance with the risk control and 
risk management strategies for all types of risks and business segments. 
The Management Board and in particular the CRO of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group ensure the availability of 
an appropriate infrastructure and suitable employees as well as the corresponding methods, standards and processes. 
The specific identification, measurement, assessment, approval, monitoring, management and limitation of relevant 
risks is done on the level of the operational units. 
The Management Board is supported by several divisions to fulfil operative risk control functions and to carry out 
responsibilities of the strategic risk management at group level. The following risk management functions report 
directly to the CRO: 
 Strategic risk management 
 Operational risk management 
 Workout Management 
 Compliance and Legal 
In its standard Management Board meetings, the Management Board regularly deals with risk topics relating to all risk 
types. If necessary, measures will be discussed and taken. 
In addition, certain cross-divisional committees have been set up to carry out risk management activities in the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. 
 Risk committee of the Supervisory Board 
 Performance Team 
 Local Operational Risk Committee

Group-wide risk and capital management 
The central component of the overall bank risk management in the enterprise-wide risk management (ERM) is the 
internal capital adequacy assessment process (ICAAP) pursuant to Pillar 2 of the Basel rules and the regulatory 
guidelines (e.g. ECB guidelines for ICAAP). 
The ERM framework is designed to assist the bank’s management in managing its risk portfolio and the coverage 
potential to ensure sufficient capital at all times in line with the nature and size of the bank’s risk profile. The rules are 
adapted to the requirements of the business and risk profile of the bank and reflect the strategic goals, i.e. the 
protection of shareholders and the creditors and the sustainable continuation of the company. 
The ERM rules are a modular and comprehensive management and control system within the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group and are a fundamental part of the control and management instruments across the Group. The ERM 
rules as an effective internal control system incorporates the following components to cover all and in particular the 
regulatory requirements: 
 Risk appetite (risk appetite statement (RAS)), limits and risk strategy 
 Portfolio and risk analysis including risk materiality assessment, concentration risk management and stress test 
 Risk-bearing capacity statement 
 Capital allocation and performance management 
 Planning of risk indicators 
 Recovery and resolution planning 
In addition to the primary goal of the ICAAP, the ensuring and sustainability of the equity endowment, the ERM 
components are used by the management as support in the implementation of the business strategy. 
Risk appetite 
The risk appetite defines the maximum level of risk that the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is willing to accept in 
following its business objectives. The overall approach incorporates a declaration regarding the willingness to take 
risks, risk limits and the roles and responsibilities of those who supervise the implementation and monitoring of the 
framework for the willingness to take risks. The limit framework (i.e., the risk appetite framework) incorporates risk 
limits that are defined in the declaration regarding the willingness to take risks and in the risk strategy, industry limits, 
maximum loan award limits and operational limits.  
The risk appetite statement (RAS) of the group serves as a strategic basis that defines the maximum tolerable risk in 
order to achieve the company targets within the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. The RAS constitutes, through the 
limits approved by the Management Board and the Risk Committee of the Supervisory Board and recognised by the 
Supervisory Board, a binding restriction within the overall risk appetite of the business activities of the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group. It is integrated and embedded in the structural processes such as business and risk strategy, 
budgeting, capital and liquidity planning, recovery plan, stress testing and remuneration framework. In addition, the 
RAS consists of key performance ratios (capital, liquidity, risk-earnings profile) for the quantitative risk/return 
management and qualitative statements in the form of fundamental risk principles that form a part of the risk 
management guidelines.  
The core risk performance ratios stipulate the thresholds for the risk/return objective and form a fundamental input in 
the annual strategy and budget planning in order to create a holistic perspective of capital, liquidity and the risk/yield 
compensation. The main goal of the RAS is: 
 to ensure that the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has sufficient resources to guarantee business operations at 
any time and to absorb stress events,  
 to establish tolerance thresholds for the risk objectives of the Group and 
 to ensure the financial strength of the Group and the robustness of its systems and checks.

The establishment of the RAS at Group level is done with foresight in order to strengthen the risk/yield management 
and to guarantee a proactive management of the risk profile. External specifications, such as regulatory requirements, 
set the limits for the RAS and thus the risk that the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is willing to take. In order to 
ensure that the Group operates within the risk appetite set as a goal, a traffic light system is applied for all key 
performance ratios. This approach facilitates the prompt forwarding of information to the management envisaged in 
the governance phase and the implementation of effective risk-minimising countermeasures. The RAS traffic light 
system is defined as follows: 
 RAS is green: The goals of the risk-yield control are within the defined thresholds 
 RAS is amber: The undercutting or exceeding of a pre-defined threshold value leads to an exchange of information 
and discussion determined in the governance process for the definition of potential countermeasures. 
 RAS is red: The undercutting or exceeding of the pre-defined limit triggers an immediate escalation within the 
framework of the governance process and immediate introduction of countermeasures. 
In addition, stressed thresholds for selected core RAS been defined, which are integrated into the assessment of 
stress test results and reported to the Management Board as an early warning indicator, thereby assisting in the 
proactive management of the risk and capital profile. 
In addition, based on the risk appetite of the Group, supplementary risk key ratios and principles are defined for the 
fundamental risk types of the risk strategy. These key performance ratios and principles support the implementation 
of the medium and long-term strategy. This management guarantees a comprehensive control of the risk decisions 
and an implementation of the risk strategy. Countermeasures are introduced as part of the regular risk management 
process in order remain within the risk appetite. 
The risk appetite of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is broken down, taking into account the approved 
proportionality guidelines, onto the relevant local subsidiaries. The local RAS is subject to the approval of the local 
management boards and the Management Board of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, and is consistent with the 
Group RAS. In addition, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group can define further mandatory requirements and limits in 
the local RAS in order to ensure compliance with the Group RAS and the risk strategy. 
In addition, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has further developed an aggregated and consolidated RAS 
overview, the Risk Dashboard, that depicts the developments of the group’s risk profile and that of the local units by 
comparing the risk potential and the risk limits. The Risk Dashboard is regularly presented to the Management Board 
and key extracts from it to the Risk Committee of the Supervisory Board in order to support the review, supervision 
and monitoring of the risk profile of the Group and of the local subsidiaries. 
ESG risk drivers are established in the risk appetite and in the risk strategy and are also part of the risk materiality 
assessment of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. They are integrated in the risk taxonomy as general or 
transversal risk drivers that influence the main risk categories such as credit, market, liquidity, non-financial risks (NFR) 
and other risks. 
Portfolio and risk analysis 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses infrastructure, systems and processes with the aid of which the portfolio 
risks entered into are identified, measured, controlled, reported and managed. Portfolio and risk analysis procedures 
are designed for the quantification, qualification and discussion of the risks in order to inform the company 
management in a timely manner. 
Risk materiality assessment 
The risk materiality assessment (RMA) is a regular process for identifying risk and to evaluate potential effects of these 
risks on the Group’s risk profile. It serves the management as a control instrument in decision with regard to the 
allocation of economic capital in Pillar 2 (ICAAP) or of liquidity buffers in the ILAAP (Internal Liquidity Adequacy 
Assessment Process), and in the definition of further risk control measures. Risk control and mitigation measures are 
adapted to the specific characteristics of each individual risk, whereby there are general specifications corresponding 
to the respective materiality level that have to be complied with.

In addition, the RMA provides decisive inputs for various risk management activities such as the definition of priorities 
and strategic measures as part of the Group’s risk strategy, the definition of limits within the risk appetite and the 
scenario design for the comprehensive stress test. 
Concentration risk management 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has implemented a process in order to identify, measure, control and manage 
risk concentrations. This process is important for ensuring the long-term continuation of the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group, primarily in a difficult market environment and under difficult economic conditions. 
The risk concentration analysis of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is carried out on an annual basis and takes 
into account concentrations within the credit, market, liquidity and operational risk as well as risk-overarching 
concentrations. Risk concentrations that are determined are taken into consideration for the scenario configuration of 
the comprehensive stress test and measured under stress conditions. The result of the risk concentration analysis 
also contributes to the recognition of fundamental risks within the framework of the risk materiality assessment and 
to the definition and calibration of the limit system of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. 
Stress tests 
The modelling of sensitivities of assets and liabilities as well as the profits and losses provide management and control 
information and help to optimise the risk/yield profile of the Group. In addition, stress tests help to strengthen the 
robustness of the risk calculation, control and management through consideration of serious but entirely plausible 
scenarios. Risk modelling and stress tests are fundamental and forward-looking elements of the internal capital 
adequacy process. Sensitivities and stress scenarios are taken into account in the planning process. 
The complex stress test tasks are scenario stress tests in which the effects of various economic scenarios, including 
feedback effects on all material risk types (credit, market, liquidity and operational risk) are taken into comprehensive 
account. In addition, effects on the respective volumes of assets and liabilities as well as profit and loss sensitivities 
are included. Reverse stress tests as well as the standard scenario stress tests are carried out. These are used to 
identify a scenario or a combination of scenarios that tests the viability of the current business model. 
Special tests are used for stress tests in order to transfer the effect of certain macroeconomic variables (e.g. GDP or 
unemployment rates) to risk parameters that depict a combination of bottom-up and top-down approaches. In the 
definition of stress parameters, sufficient granularity taking account of particular features is particularly important (e.g. 
specific developments in countries, industries or segments). 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has integrated climate risks in the comprehensive stress test. In particular, both 
physical risk as well as transition risks based on forecast climate changes are included. The further development of 
the climate-based stress analysis will support the strategic overall approach of the Group regarding the climate risk. 
The results of the in-house stress test are analysed in order to be able to decide on suitable countermeasures if 
necessary. The comprehensive stress test last created did not show any breach of the stressed RAS threshold values. 
Risk-bearing capacity statement  
The calculation of capital adequacy defines the method of calculating capital adequacy for Pillar 2. In contrast to the 
normative perspective of Pillar 1 which relates to the Group’s ability to fulfil all capital-related regulatory and 
supervisory requirements, the RTFR is based on an economic perspective of the approach of Pillar 1+, assuming the 
continuation of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group in accordance with the ECB guidelines for ICAAP and determines 
whether the Group has sufficient capital in order to cover all relevant risks to which it is exposed. The economic and 
the normative perspective are integrated in all fundamental business management activities and decisions. With this 
approach, the Group increases efficiency and ensures the comparability with the Pillar 1 calculation. On the basis of 
the results of the risk materiality assessment, the economic capital for the relevant risk types is taken into account as 
approved by the Management Board. The economic capital requirements are then compared with the internally 
available capital (cover potential) in order to cover the risks of the Group in Pillar 2. Both the economic capital and the 
coverage potential are calculated on the basis of the CRR consolidated group of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group 
as the parent company and on the basis of the IFRS accounting standards.

from the business activity of the Group, at any time (in normal and stressed form). At the end of 2024, the economic

The Directive (EU) 2014/59 (Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive – BRRD) – in the respective version – is being 
implemented in national law in Austria through the Recovery and Resolution Act (Sanierungs- und Abwicklungsgesetz 
– BaSAG). On 7 June 2019, a legislative banking package (EU Banking Package) was announced in the Official Journal 
of the European Union. This EU banking package includes, in the respective version, Directive (EU) No. 2013/36 (CRD 
IV) and Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013 (CRR) and the BRRD and Regulation (EU) No. 806/2014 (SRMR). The EU 
Banking Package entered into force on 27 June 2019 and was implemented in national law in Austria on 28 June 
2021.  
Recovery planning. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group sends an updated Group recovery plan to the Erste Group 
every year. Pursuant to the requirements of the Federal Law on the Recovery and Resolution of Banks (BaSAG), Erste 
Group sends a group recovery plan to the Joint Supervisory Team (JST) every year. The Group recovery plan is 
regularly assessed by the ECB. It describes potential measures for the restocking of the capital and liquidity resources 
of the bank in order to be able to manage a number of both idiosyncratic and market-wide stress scenarios. The 
recovery framework is largely coordinated with the risk appetite framework with regard to indicators and their limits 
in order to ensure a comprehensive enterprise-wide risk management. It is decisive here that in a serious crisis 
situation close to the default or impending default of the bank sufficient recovery capacity is available in order to be 
able to take the recovery indicators back into the green area again. The sequence of reporting defined in the recovery 
plan facilitates a prompt and appropriate possibility of intervention in the event of recovery. In addition, the assessment 
of the Group recovery plan and the classification of the entire recovery capacity is part of the SREP (Supervisory 
Review and Evaluation Process) assessment. 
Resolution planning. The Erste Group collaborates in the creation of resolution plans through the resolution authorities 
that are envisaged in the BaSAG and Resolution (EU) No. 806/2014 on the uniform resolution mechanism (SRM 
Regulation). The legal framework permits a multiple-point-of-entry (MPE) resolution strategy or a single-point-of-
entry (SPE) resolution strategy. The joint decision taken by the resolution authorities in the resolution council stipulates 
for Erste Group the MPE approach, comprising six separate resolution groups with subsidiaries in the main countries 
of Erste Group in Central and Eastern Europe and in Austria, however, with SPE approach within a country. This results 
in resolution groups in Austria, the Czech Republic, Croatia, Hungary, Romania, Slovenia and Slovakia. With a MPE 
strategy, a banking group thus has several resolution units as the entry point for the resolution. The resolution plans 
(including resolution strategy and MREL decision) are regularly updated by the resolution authorities and are subject 
to the joint decision by the resolution council. Steiermärkische Sparkasse is part of the Austrian resolution group.

Main differences between the IFRS and regulatory consolidated groups due to the different requirements under IFRS, 
CRR and BWG: 
According to CRR and the Banking Act (BWG), the consolidated group under supervisory law primarily includes banks 
pursuant to Article 4 (1) (1) CRR, securities trading firms pursuant to Article 4 (1) (2) CRR, providers of ancillary 
services pursuant to Article 4 (1) (18) CRR and financial institutions pursuant to Article 4 (1) (26) CRR. By contrast, in 
accordance with IFRS, all other entities that are not consolidated according to CRR, such as insurance companies, 
must be included in the IFRS consolidated group. 
Pursuant to the CRR, companies can be excluded from the consolidated group pursuant to supervisory law. Pursuant 
to Article 19 (1) CRR, companies can be excluded from the consolidated group pursuant to supervisory law if the total 
sum of their assets and off-balance-sheet positions is below the lower of the two following amounts: EUR 10 million 
or 1% of the total sum of the assets and off-balance-sheet positions of the parent company. The Erste Group and the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group apply Article 19(1) CRR. 
Pursuant to Article 19 (2) CRR, companies can also be excluded if the thresholds defined in Article 19 (1) CRR are 
exceeded but the companies can be neglected under supervisory law. The exclusion of entities on the basis of Article 
19(2) CRR requires prior approval by the competent authorities. The Erste Group and the Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
Group apply Article 19 (2) CRR for companies that only exceed the thresholds defined in Article 19 (1) CRR 
insignificantly and complies with the requirements for the approval process that are also defined in this article. The 
Erste Group and the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group do not apply Article 19(2) CRR to credit institutions and 
investment firms. Steiermärkische Sparkasse applies Article 19(2) CRR in the same way. 
The Austrian savings banks are subsidiaries of the Erste Group and, due to the joint liability agreements, a part of the

31. Credit risk: Reviewing and monitoring credit risks 
ESG risk management 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group integrates ESG factors in its risk management and industry strategy framework. 
In the process, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses an ESG factor heat map that is provided by the Erste Group 
in order to identify the industry segments that could be exposed to ESG risk factors or that are more susceptible for

ANNUAL FINANCIAL REPORT 2024 – STEIERMÄRKISCHE SPARKASSE GROUP 
95
ESG risks. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses industry strategies and loan award standards in order to 
support portfolio management with regard to ESG risks.  
In addition, an ESG risk framework was introduced in the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group to assess material ESG 
factors and the associated risks in the credit process. In this way, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group takes ESG 
risk criteria into account in loan decisions. 
In major corporate, commercial real estate and residential real estate transactions, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
Group conducts a systematic ESG analysis based on an internal, digital ESG assessment questionnaire. The 
questionnaire is a mandatory requirement within the framework of the loan and monitoring process. Through a 
comprehensive ESG risk assessment, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group can establish the positive or negative 
influence of ESG factors on the customers’ financial performance. The questionnaire makes it possible to identify ESG 
risks or ESG opportunities of the customers. 
Certain questions in the questionnaire can also require an accompanying assessment in order to understand the type 
and severity of the ESG risks that the customers are exposed to. The questionnaire is an important part of defined 
loan applications and is updated at least once a year; it makes it possible for the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group to 
understand the business model of the customers in connection with the transition to a low-carbon economy.  
In addition, ESG-relevant data are collected for certain types of securities pursuant to the definitions included in the 
Group Collateral Management Policy for the valuation, documentation and reporting of real estate collateral. 
Environmental aspects that influence the value of the collateral must be taken into account in the real estate valuation, 
which can result in a higher or lower valuation result. In addition, risks also need to be taken into account that result 
from social (e.g. location and transport, mass urbanisation - as indicators for the easy accessibility for the population) 
and governance factors (such as inappropriate business practices such as tax evasion or bribing of the financed 
company that is the owner of the building serving as collateral). For commercial real estate of a certain size, ESG-
relevant information incl. calculations of the ecological footprint of the building, including information about the use of 
space, the space efficiency and the existence of a certification as a sustainable building is collected in the course of 
the “Technical Object Rating”.  
Through ESG risks, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is confronted with additional challenges. With regard to the 
measurement of the credit risk and the internal models, a corresponding project was started in 2022 in the Erste 
Group to define and record relevant climate risk drivers for rating systems in order to explicitly ensure the consideration 
of climate risks in future model development initiatives. With the LGD models, the climate risk is taken into 
consideration indirectly via the collateral value. Since 2023, ESG factors have been taken into consideration in the 
company rating as soft facts. 
It is also analysed how ESG risks can be integrated in the measurement of the expected credit loss. As of 31 December 
2024, no overlays are seen as necessary for this. 
For the valuation and the management of physical risks, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses intelligence data 
from Munich Re. In the past year, the Erste Group, together with the University of Graz, conducted a materiality test 
of physical risks in order to identify the most important risks and climate change scenarios that are relevant for the 
collateral portfolio. The results of this analysis, which emphasise the significance of flooding, fire, drought, rise in sea 
level, and heat, are integrated in the collateral management, whereby a moderate climate change scenario of a 2 to 
3 ° C rise in temperature until 2100 (Representative Concentration Pathway 4.5 / Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2, 
developed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) is used as a reasonable assumption. In the case of very 
high physical risks for a location, the collateral value would be negatively influenced. 
In order to evaluate the potential effects of the physical risk, a model developed internally for physical climate risks 
was used within the framework of the internal stress test. Applying the climate risk scores provided by Munich Re for 
the collateral of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, the flooding risk was defined as the most important risk for the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group.

Methods of credit risk management 
Credit risks develop in the classical credit and investment business of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group.  
Operative loan decisions are taken by the local units responsible for the credit risk management and at Group level by 
the Operative Credit Risk Management. 
In compliance with EU-wide and local regulatory requirements, the credit risk management in the retail and corporate 
business takes into consideration the strategic alignment of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group and provides 
private individuals as well as small and medium-sized enterprises with loans within their financial capacities. 
Internal rating system 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group regulates its credit guidelines and credit approval procedures within the 
framework of business and risk strategies. The policies are regularly reviewed and, if necessary, adapted at least once 
a year. Taking into account the type, the scope and the risk content of the transactions and borrowers concerned, 
they cover the entire credit award process. When approving credit, individual information such as the credit rating of 
the customer, the credit type, the collateralisation, the contractual configuration and other risk-reducing factors are 
taken into account. 
The loan default risk is assessed in the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group on the basis of the default probability of the 
customers. For each credit commitment and within the framework of each credit decision, the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group awards a rating as a specific measurement for the loan default risk (internal rating). The internal 
rating of all customers is updated on an ad hoc basis, but at least once a year (annual rating review). This is done at 
correspondingly shorter intervals for customers in workout. 
The main purpose of the internal ratings is their use in the decision-making process for lending and in stipulating the 
terms and conditions of loans. In addition, as a result of the internal ratings, the necessary competence level within 
the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group and the monitoring procedures for existing receivables are also determined. On 
the quantitative level, the internal ratings influence the necessary risk costs, the loss allowances and, if applicable, 
the risk-weighted assets according to Pillar 1 and 2. 
For Group companies that use the approach based on internal ratings (IRB), internal ratings are a fundamental input 
parameter to determine the risk-weighted assets. They are also used in the Group-wide calculation of economic equity 
requirements in accordance with Pillar 2. A default probability is indicated for this within the framework of the 
calibration process for the portfolios of every risk category. The calibration is done individually for each rating method. 
Default probabilities constitute a 1-year default probability based on long-term average default rates. In addition, the 
bank adds safety margins to the calculated default probabilities. 
All available information fundamental for the assessment of the loan default risk is incorporated into internal ratings. 
In the event of borrowers that cannot be assigned to the retail private sector, the internal ratings take into account the 
financial strength of the customer, the possibility of external support, flexibility in the company financing, general 
company data and, if applicable, historical credit rating data from external sources. In the case of retail private 
customers, internal ratings are primarily based on data about the payment behaviour towards the bank (if available) 
and, if applicable, financial information from credit information agencies and they also take into account information 
that is provided by the respective customer, and general demographic data. Upper thresholds for the rating are applied

97
on the basis of the country of the registered office (for cross-border financing) and the affiliation to a group of 
economically linked companies. 
The internal rating models and risk parameters used are developed and continually developed further by teams of 
specialists in collaboration with risk management. All rating models are the object of an annual review of their 
estimates that includes the incorporation of the latest data into the estimate of the risk parameters, and also a regular 
complete model audit. This model development follows uniform standards across the Group with regard to 
methodology and documentation and is based on the relevant data of the respective market. This guarantees the 
availability of rating models with the highest possible forecasting accuracy and ability to differentiate risk in all core 
countries. 
The central organisational unit of the Erste Group – Model Validation – is responsible for the definition of validation 
methods and standards that are applied for all credit risk models. All Pillar 1, material Pillar 2 and IFRS9 models are 
subject to an annual validation, whereas a regular validation cycle is implemented for non-material Pillar 2 and IFRS9 
models. On the validation side, both qualitative and quantitative methods are applied in order to test the conceptual 
accuracy, the quantitative model quality and the model use. The validation results are adopted in the corresponding 
model committees and, in the case of IRB models, then communicated to the supervisory authorities. In addition to 
the validation, there is a regularly review of the performance of the IRB rating models, among others based on the 
changes in the number of new defaults and early phases of payment arrears. 
Approvals of all new models, model changes, amendments in risk parameters, amendments in the Group-wide 
methodological standards and other model-based aspects are issued according to the dual approval procedure within 
the Group. The corresponding structures of the holding and of the local model committee reflect joint responsibilities 
for decisions regarding Pillar 1 IRB and Pillar 2 credit risk models as well as for methods regarding IFRS 9 parameters. 
Responsibilities are assigned depending on the scope of the model (Group-wide or locally developed models). In this 
context, the committees Strategic Risk Executive Committee and Strategic Risk Management Committee in the Erste 
Group and the Risk Management Team (comprising representatives of defined Sparkassen and the Erste Group) have 
been set up. 
The ultimate responsibility for all models that are used within the Erste Group (on a consolidated level) lies with the 
Group CRO. 
Classification of credit risk 
For the purpose of reporting with regard to the loan quality, the customers of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group 
are consolidated in the following four risk categories: 
Low risk. Typical regional customers with a stable, long-standing relationship with the Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
Group or large, internationally renowned customers. Very good to satisfactory financial situation; low probability of 
occurrence of financial difficulties compared to the respective market in which the customers operate. Retail 
customers with a long-standing business relationship to the bank or customers who use a broad range of products. 
No relevant payment arrears currently or in the last twelve months. New business is typically performed with 
customers in this risk category. 
Requiring comment. Potentially liable non-retail customers who perhaps already had payment arrears/defaults in the 
past or could have difficulties in the repayment of debts in the medium term. Retail customers with possible payment 
problems in the past that led to an early reminder. These customers recently demonstrated good payment behaviour. 
Elevated risk. The borrower is prone in the short term to negative financial and economic developments and has an 
increased default probability. In some cases, restructuring measures are impending or have already been carried out. 
Such receivables are usually handled in specialised risk management departments. 
Non-performing. At least one of the default criteria according to Article 178 CRR applies to the borrower, among 
others, full repayment improbable, interest or capital repayments of a fundamental receivable overdue by more than 
90 days; debt restructuring with loss for borrower; realisation of a loss or opening of insolvency proceedings. For all 
customer segments, including retail customers, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses the customer perspective;
