be non-performing. All non-performing receivables are also seen as defaulted.  
The materiality threshold for the determination of 90-days overdue receivables is applied for statement of financial 
position risk positions on customer level and compared daily with the materiality threshold defined throughout the 
Group (unless the local supervisory authority stipulates other threshold values). 
 For retail customers there is an absolute threshold of EUR 100 and a relative threshold of 1%. 
 For non-retail customers there is an absolute threshold of EUR 500 and a relative threshold of 1%. 
On the basis of the calibration of internal probabilities of default (probabilities of default, PDs) for regulatory purposes 
to the default rates published by rating agencies, the corresponding external customer rating is used for the allocation 
to risk categories. Average one-year default rates from long-term periods are used for the ratings of rating agencies. 
The Bosnian supervisory authority has issued a temporary regulation for local banks that states that an increase in 
interest of more than 2% for private customer loans may not result in any default. That is why as of 31 December 
2024 a credit risk volume of EUR 1.6 million is held in Stage 2 instead of Stage 3 in the retail portfolio concerned.  
Reviewing and monitoring credit risks 
 
All credit limits and transactions within these limits are reviewed at least once a year. Customer-related credit risk 
limits are monitored on a daily basis by the internal limit management system and in the event of limits being exceeded 
the necessary measures are introduced. 
A standardised early warning system has been implemented throughout the Group for the forward-looking recognition 
of negative developments. The early warning indicators are monitored by the local units of the operational risk 
management and the workout management for the respective segments. If early warning signals are established and 
validated, a review of the entire customer exposure and the credit rating will be performed. If necessary, appropriate 
measures to reduce risk will be initiated. Within the framework of regular watchlist discussions, customers with a poor 
credit rating will be monitored and precautionary measures discussed. The monitoring and credit rating check of 
smaller companies and of retail customers is based on an automated early warning system. In retail risk management, 
among others, a deterioration in quality in new commitments or declining effectiveness in the collection of receivables 
are signs of potential unfavourable portfolio developments and require appropriate countermeasures. In addition, the 
monitoring for the customers is performed for whom early warning signals have been established, even if they still 
comply with the contractual repayment obligations.  
Negative developments of the non-performing loans and the loans with an increased risk are regularly monitored, 
discussed and reported. In the event of further negative developments, the customers are supported by units 
specialised in workout in order to maximise repayments.

33.  Use of collateral 
Recognition of collateral 
Collateral management is integrated in the Strategic or Operative Risk Management department. With the “Group 
Collateral Management Policy Part 1 Credit Collateral” or with the “Liability Scheme Collateral Management Policy”, 
among others, group-wide uniform valuation standards for loan securities are determined. It is thus ensured that the 
loan decision process is standardised with regard to the collateral values used.  
All collateral permitted within the Group are shown in the Group Collateral Catalogue. The locally approved securities 
are defined by the respective bank, taking into account the applicable national legal provisions. The valuation and new 
valuation of the securities is done according to specified principles, differentiated according to the type of security 
and on the basis of internal work instructions that are oriented to the regulations of supervisory law. Whether a type 
of security defined individual securities can be recognised to reduce the credit risk for the regulatory calculation of 
own funds is, after a check whether the respective regulatory requirements are met, subject to a decision by the 
enterprise-wide risk management of the Erste Group. The operational risk management monitors compliance with the 
processes specified for the classification of the eligible collateral in the envisaged categories. 
Main types of credit securities 
In most cases, the following collateral is accepted: 
 real estate: both residential and commercially used real estate; 
 financial securities: securities and account balances as well as life insurances; 
 guarantees: issued by countries, the public sector, financial institutes, companies and private individuals. All 
guarantors must have a minimum credit rating, which is checked annually. 
 movable assets: company equipment, goods, machines and vehicles; 
 receivables and rights: trade receivables, leasehold rights, share rights to companies. 
Valuation and management of securities  
The securities are valued on the basis of current market values, taking into account utilisation proceeds to be 
generated over an appropriate period of time. The valuation proceedings are specified and their technical application 
is done using IT by authorised employees in the respective countries. The upper limit for eligible collateral is equal to 
the amount of the collateralised transaction.  
The valuation of real estate may only be done by expert appraisers independent of the credit decision process 
according to international, European or national standards, whereby the valuation procedures to be applied are 
specified to the appraisers. The selection of the appraisers is done according to internally defined criteria with regard 
to their qualification and independence. An appraiser can only appraise a property two consecutive times; then the 
appraisal has to be done by another appraiser. In order to ensure quality, the property appraisers and valuations are 
constantly reviewed. 
The estimates and discounts used for the valuation are based on experiences gained in the past by the credit 
restructuring departments and the results from the revenues data collection from the utilisation of the securities. The 
valuation rates are adjusted regularly –  at least yearly –  to the realisation proceeds, taking into account foreseeable 
scenarios (such as expected real estate price development based on elemental events). 
Collateral is periodically remeasured; this process is automated as far as possible. In the case of external sources of 
data, corresponding interfaces will be used. The maximum deadlines for the remeasurement of individual collateral 
are prescribed and their fulfilment is monitored by Risk Management with system support. Independently of the new 
valuation to be carried out on a periodic basic, this also has to be done when information is available that indicates 
the reduction of the value of the securities or defined threshold values are exceeded. Particularly real estate being 
developed with significant exceeding of costs or time, as well as real estate secured with loans with an increased risk, 
are monitored or revalued with a higher frequency.

Concentration risks from credit risk mitigation techniques can affect an individual customer, but also a portfolio defined 
by region, industry or type of collateral. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group as a retail bank has no concentrations 
of collateral from customers on account of its customer structure and the various markets in which the bank operates. 
In order to avoid possible concentrations in the corporate customer business, all guarantees submitted as loan 
collateral are taken into account in the loan decision process, along with the loan liabilities. The guarantees granted 
by countries, the public sector and banks must be within limits approved for the party providing the collateral.  
Collateral properties acquired in the course of enforcement measures will be duly sold. The proceeds are used to 
reduce or repay the outstanding receivable. In general, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group does not use property 
acquired in this manner for its own business operations. This is essentially commercial land and buildings. As of 31 
December 2024, there were no such assets in the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group.

34.  Measurement of the expected credit loss 
The general principles and standards regarding loss allowances for credit losses are regulated at the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group in internal guidelines. In accordance with IFRS 9, loan loss allowances are calculated for all items of 
credit risk exposure that are measured at amortised cost or at fair value through other comprehensive income. They 
incorporate bonds, loans and advances, sight deposits on nostro accounts at business banks, receivables from 
financing leasing and trade receivables. In addition, loss allowances for financial guarantees and non-utilised credit 
commitments are calculated if they fall under the area of application of the IFRS 9 provisions. 
Classification to stages and definition of impaired financial instruments 
Three stages are shown for the determination of the expected credit loss (ECL). The stage approach is used for 
financial instruments subject to the impairment requirements of IFRS 9 that are not already purchased or originated 
credit-impaired (POCI) financial assets at the time of accrual. The latter form a separate category. The assignment of 
the financial instruments to one of the three stages depends on the status of the impairment and the assessment of 
the development of the credit risk. The three stages are described in the chapter “Financial instruments - Material 
accounting principles”, in the section “Impairments of financial instruments”. 
Determination of a significant increase in the credit risk 
The determination of a significant increase in credit risk (SICR) between initial recognition and the end of the reporting 
period is one of the key factors for the recognition of the expected credit loss in accordance with IFRS 9. For this 
purpose, quantitative and qualitative indicators for the determination of a significant increase in the credit risk are 
defined across all portfolios and product types, including those overdue by more than 30 days. 
Quantitative criteria. Quantitative indicators for the determination of a significant increase in the credit risk include 
disadvantageous changes to the lifetime probability of default (LT PD) calculated over the entire term, during which 
the significance is determined by means of a comparison with the change thresholds. Thresholds have been defined 
for significant increases in credit risk that relate to both relative and absolute changes in the probability of default 
since initial recognition. A significant increase in the credit risk results when both relative and absolute threshold values 
are exceeded. 
The ratio of current annualised total term default probability and annualised total term default probability at initial 
recognition is calculated as a relative parameter, whereby in each case the residual term of the financial instrument is 
taken into consideration. A defined threshold is exceeded if this indicator is equal to or higher than the threshold. 
These relative thresholds to determine a significant increase in the credit risk are determined at the level of customer 
segments or as required on the level of the customer rating for the Group company and are subject to a first-time and 
continuous validation. 
There are some portfolios for which the quantitative criteria of a significant increase in the credit risk are determined 
on the basis of the nominal ratings instead of on the basis of the probability of default. If a downgrading exceeds a 
pre-determined number of rating stages, this results in a significant increase in the credit risk. This rule is applied 
above all to lease and factoring receivables. 
The absolute threshold refers to the difference between the total lifetime probability of default when used for the first 
time and the residual term probability of default at the current point in time, whereby annualised or cumulative figures 
are used. The threshold is defined at a maximum of 50 base points and serves as a security threshold (backstop) for 
migrations within the best rating stages. In such cases, relative threshold values can be exceeded but as the probability 
of default expected over the total term is very low overall, this does not trigger any significant increase in the credit 
risk.

Qualitative criteria. Qualitative indicators for the determination of a significant increase in the credit risk incorporate 
the taking of deferral measures and the transfer of the customer support to the Workout department and early warning 
indicators and information about fraud. The determination of some qualitative indicators is based inherently on the 
expert assessment of credit risks that has to be done appropriately and in a timely manner. The Group-wide guidelines 
and processes specific to the institute in this regard (which were adapted in the course of the changeover to IFRS 9 
if necessary) guarantee the necessary management framework. These indicators are used internally to recognise an 
insolvency or a higher probability that the borrower will become bankrupt or that an increased risk of default exists for 
a foreseeable period of time.  
In addition to the qualitative determinants on the customer level, the determination of a significant increase in the 
credit risk is carried out on portfolio level if the increase in the credit risk at transaction or customer level only occurs 
after a certain delay or if it is only discernible on portfolio level.  
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has introduced additional criteria for the collection valuation of a significant 
increase in the credit risk based on numerous geopolitical conflicts and the resulting macroeconomic effects on 
portfolio level. 
Security threshold (backstop) 
A security threshold is used by there being a significant increase in the credit risk when contractual payment 
obligations are overdue by more than 30 days. The validation found that this criterion is not a material trigger for a 
Stage 2 classification. 
Calculation of the expected credit loss – Explanations on input data and evaluation 
Impairments are calculated on individual level or on portfolio level. 
The individual calculation method is applied for fundamentally defaulted customers in Stage 3 or POCI. It involves 
individually determining the difference between the gross carrying amount and present value of the expected cash 
flows estimated by workout risk managers. They are discounted on the basis of the effective interest rate (for POCI 
financial instruments on the basis of the credit-adjusted effective interest rate). In the case of financial guarantees, 
the discounting rate should, however, reflect the current market estimates of the monetary value and of the specific 
risk of the cashflow. As implemented by the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, this means applying a risk-free interest 
rate as an approximation. 
A customer who has defaulted is classified as individually significant if the entire statement of financial position and 
off-balance-sheet credit risk volume is above a certain materiality threshold. Otherwise, the customer is classified as 
insignificant, whereby a rule-based approach is taken for the calculation of loan loss allowances. In this approach, 
loan loss allowances are calculated as the product of gross carrying amount and loss given default, whereby loss given 
default depends among other things on the duration of the default and the status of recovery and resolution processes. 
loss allowances for receivables towards non-defaulted customers (i.e. financial instruments in Stage 1 and Stage 2) 
are calculated independently of their amount on the basis of a rule-based approach. In the calculation of rule-based 
loss allowances, the corresponding risk positions must be grouped into homogeneous clusters on the basis of common 
risk characteristics. The criteria for the grouping can vary according to customer segment (retail customers, corporate 
customers) and include product type, collateral type, repayment type, loan-to-value ranges and rating ranges. 
The loss allowances for credit losses are calculated on a monthly basis in the contractual currency on the level of the 
individual risk positions. For the calculation of loss allowances, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group uses an 
impairment model on the basis of a three-stage approach, which gives twelve-month or lifetime expected credit loss. 
The expected credit loss is the product of discounted exposure at default (EAD), which includes a credit conversion 
factor (CCF) for Off-balance-sheet items, multiplied by probability of default (PD) and loss given default (LGD). The 
parameters are defined as follows:  
 PD stands for the probability that an obligor does not meet its financial obligations and defaults, either during the 
next 12 months (one-year probability of default, 1Y PD) for risk positions in Stage 1 or during the remaining total 
term (“lifetime probability of default, LT PD) for risk positions in the Stages 2 and 3 and for POCI risk positions.

108
 EAD is the amount that the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group expects to be owed at the time of default, either over 
the next twelve months (one-year exposure at default, 1Y EAD) for risk positions in Stage 1 or over the remaining 
lifetime (lifetime exposure at default, LT EAD) for risk positions Stage 2 and 3 and POCI risk positions. The estimate 
includes the current balance, the expected repayments and the expected drawings within the agreed framework 
until the time of default. 
 LGD embodies the expectation of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group with regard to the amount of the loss in the 
event of a defaulted receivable. Loss given default varies according to type of counterparty, type and seniority of 
the exposure and availability of collateral or other credit support. Loss given default is expressed as a percentage 
of exposure at default (EAD). 
Lifetime parameters 
The lifetime probability of default (lifetime PD) is determined by observing the historical defaults over an available 
history. The calculated Lifetime PDs are extrapolated, e.g., through matrix multiplication in order to ensure that the 
final Lifetime PD covers the term of the loans from the first time they are recorded. It is assumed to be equal for all 
financial assets in the same portfolio and the same rating range. In addition, the risk country is taken into consideration 
as an additionally relevant characteristic for the lifetime PD for the central models of the Group (Large) Corporates 
using the forward-looking information (FLI). 
One-year and lifetime exposure at default is calculated using expected payment profiles, which vary according to 
product type. The lifetime exposure value is calculated using a repayment schedule or repayment type (annuity, linear, 
bullet). For undrawn loan commitments, the credit conversion factor is estimated to the reflect the expected credit 
risk exposure at default (EAD). 
Loss given default is estimated on the basis of historical loss observations on a lifetime curve for each point in time. 
The risk parameters that are used in the calculation of the expected credit losses take into account the information 
available on the key reporting date regarding past events, current conditions and forecasts of future economic 
developments. Due to the characteristics of the respective portfolio and taking into account the IFRS rules, the risk 
parameters that are incorporated into the calculation of the rule-based loss allowances, can deviate from the risk 
parameters that are used in the calculation of the capital requirement and are determined on the basis of a through-
the-cycle analysis.

Loss allowances that are formed as a result of the utilisation of non-revolving loan commitments are shown in the 
column “Additions”. That is why the additions for Stage 2 and 3 indicated in this column constitute transfers from 
Stage 1 between the point in time of the credit commitment and the use of the respective credit. They also reflect 
transactions in which the recording of the loss allowances was done for the first time after these transactions had 
already been assigned to Stage 2 based on the use of the collective assessment of the significant increase in the loan 
risk described in Note 37. 
In the column “Transfer between stages” net changes in loss allowances are shown that due to changes in the credit 
risk resulted in a transfer of the underlying loans and advances to customers AC from Stage 1 (as at 1 January 2024 
or at the time of the initial recording) to Stage 2 or 3 (as of 31 December 2024) – or conversely. There is an increase 
in the loss allowances formed due to transfers from Stage 1 to Stage 2 or 3. This is shown in the lines “Stage 2” or 
“Stage 3”. Transfers from Stage 2 or 3 to Stage 1 result in a reversal of loss allowances, which is shown in the “Stage 
1” line. The effect with no impact on profit or loss and which arises from the reallocation of the loss allowance amounts 
recorded before the transfer between the stages is shown in the column "Other changes to the credit risk (net)".

on the lifetime expected credit losses from AC loans and advances to customers. This relates both to AC loans and

classified as POCI. For the year 2024, this effect amounted cumulatively to EUR 11.5 million (2023: EUR 7.7 million) 
and also reflects the interest income not recorded during the year from the underlying loans and advances to 
customers AC.

37. Scenarios for the consideration of forward-looking information and crisis 
effects 
Overview of scenarios for the consideration of future-related information 
Consideration of forward-looking information 
The parameters are determined so that they reflect the risk as a point-in-time measurement taking into account 
forward-looking (FLI) information. A basic forecast and alternative scenarios for selected macroeconomic variables 
are created for this. The alternative scenarios are, jointly with the scenario weighting, derived from the basic forecasts 
that are created with a few exceptions by the Research department of the Erste Group. With the aid of these scenarios, 
the "neutral" probabilities of default (and in places also the loss in the event of default) are adjusted by macroeconomic 
models that establish a link between relevant macroeconomic variables and risk drivers. Forward-looking information 
is taken into account in the determination of the expected credit loss in the first three years. The parameters for the 
remaining term from the 4th year are determined on the basis of cycle-based observations.  
The undistorted and scenario-weighted expected credit loss is therefore derived from the weighted results for each 
macroeconomic scenario using forward-looking information. Typical macroeconomic variables are, for instance, the 
real gross domestic product (GDP), the unemployment rate and the rate of inflation. The selection of variables is also 
dependent on the availability of reliable forecasts for the respective local market. The main indicator for the estimate 
of the economic development and basis for deriving alternative scenarios is the GDP: In addition, the economic effects 
of the ongoing war in Ukraine and the arising conflicts in the Near East resulted in an increase in inflation and/or the 
interest rates. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group adapted the macro-shift models in order to reflect the expected 
effects on the credit risk parameters.  
The FLI macro shift models are regularly recalibrated in order to take into account the most important macro variables, 
whereby the variables with the highest statistical relevance are included. In the case of the central models for Group 
(Large) Corporates, a separate central organisational unit of the Erste Group is responsible for the review of the lifetime 
PDs, including the future-based information which is based on the risk country and differentiates the macro 
development in the various countries. 
The sensitivities when assigning to a stage and loss allowances with regard to macro scenarios are shown in the 
section Collective Valuation further below. 
Collective valuation 
In addition to the standard valuation of the significant increase in the credit risk the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group 
uses a collective valuation of the significant increase in the credit risk (stage overlay), i.e., a shift into Stage 2 on the 
basis of predefined portfolio characteristics in light of newly occurring risks that are not covered by standard models. 
This approach was agreed with all subsidiaries concerned and approved by the respective management bodies.

Exceptions to the collective valuation of the significant increase in the credit risk were necessary if special 
characteristics were established and it was duly documented why they behave differently to the rest of the portfolio. 
In December 2024, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group applied the collective valuation of the significant increase 
in the credit risk for certain sectors. The collective valuation of the significant increase in the credit risk applied in 
December 2023 for cyclical industries that is based on the correlation to the economic downturn, and for selected 
industries from the energy sector (production and distribution of energies and heat), including energy-intensive 
industries (metal and chemicals) were removed or converted: 
 the collective valuation of the significant increase in the credit risk for selected industries from the energy sector 
due to the distortions on the energy market with impact on the availability and the price of gas/energy: This was 
suspended in June 2024 on the basis of the regular valuation of the boundary conditions (exit triggers) for the 
collective valuation of the significant increase in the credit risk. The conclusion was drawn that the risk in the case 
of the energy sector / energy-intensive industries was reduced (sufficient gas reserves in Europe, stabilised energy 
prices). 
 The collective valuation of the significant increase in the credit risk for cyclical industries due to the war in Ukraine 
as a combination of industries with a correlation to the economic downturn (cyclical industries) and the one-year 
IFRS-PD. The continuing high inflation and the reduction in available income continue to slow private consumption, 
whereas the high global uncertainty and the high refinancing conditions are having negative effects on investments 
and industrial activity. Whereas some industries developed better in 2023, which was confirmed by the rating 
reviewed in 2024, others continue to be confronted with high warehouse stocks, ongoing problems in the supply 
chain and cost inflation as well as additionally with reduced demand. The latter is not yet reflected in the customers’ 
financial data, and a downgrading of the ratings continues to be expected. That is why the collective valuation of 
the significant increase in the credit risk for cyclical industries was converted/revalued in November 2024 in order 
to guarantee an improved interlinking with internal risk management processes. The collective valuation of the 
significant increase in the credit risk was linked to the industry strategy (industry stage overlay) that reflects risks 
and changes in the risk valuation to which our portfolio is exposed, instead of the previously used general definition 
of cyclical industries. The industry strategy incorporates all twelve corporate industries and their sub-segments. 
The industries are systematically valued pursuant to the risk management framework of the Erste Group (industry 
strategies and main risks). However, potential risks have possible not yet manifested themselves on the customer 
level and are not yet incorporated in the financial data or ratings of the customers. That is why using a threshold 
value that is defined by the one-year IFRS-PD, customers are identified who are potentially affected, which reflects 
that a better rating classification (and thus PD) defines the credit standing on the customer level. 
With a part of the retail portfolio at Sparkasse Bank Bosnia, interest rate increases on portfolio level were technically 
limited by temporary measures. After the end of these measures, the bank assumes that the interest rates will be 
increased again to a level that corresponds to the original loan agreements. That is why the bank has carried out an 
additional collective stage valuation for this portfolio. As of 31 December 2024, the affected credit risk volume 
amounts to EUR 4.0 million and the additional loss allowances EUR 0.1 million. 
In November 2024, a new collective valuation of the significant increase of the credit risk was also introduced in 
Bosnia and Herzegovina due to flooding in order to cover physical risks. This resulted in an additional credit risk volume 
of EUR 24.5 million in Stage 2 and an increase in the expected credit loss by EUR 0.3 million.

Performing forbearance receivables become non-performing if, in the course of the monitoring period of a minimum 
of two years after being given forbearance status, at least one of the following criteria is met: 
 complete or partial waiver of a receivable through (partial) depreciation; 
 another forbearance measure is taken; 
 the customer goes more than 30 days into arrears for a receivable with forbearance status and the customer has 
already been classified as non-performing in the past; 
 the customer fulfils one of the criteria defined in the definition of default; 
 for corporate customers when no final restructuring/recovery can be agreed within 18 months after the first 
forbearance measure. 
The non-performing forbearance status can be rescinded and transferred to the status Performing on probation/trial 
if there is no reason for a classification as non-performing and the following conditions are met: 
 There are no grounds for a classification as non-performing; 
 The borrowers have proven the ability to meet the contractual conditions after loss of the forbearance classification; 
 At least one year has passed since one of the following events: 
o since additional forbearance measures were granted; 
o since the end of deferment; 
o since the classification of the customers as non-performing; 
o since the receivables was classified as non-performing forbearance.

41. Market risk 
Definition and overview 
The market risk is the risk of a loss that can occur due to disadvantageous changes in market prices and parameters 
derived from them. These changes in market value can appear in the income statement, in the overall statement of 
recognised income and expenses or in the hidden reserves. In the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, market risk is 
divided into interest rate risk, credit spread risk, currency risk, and share risk. Both trading and non-trading 
transactions are affected.  
Trading book according to Article 94 CRR 
In the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, a trading book pursuant to Art. 94 CRR is only operated at Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse (trading book activity of a low volume). 
Sensitivity analysis of market risks 
For the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, rate shocks scenarios pursuant to the EBA Regulatory Technical Standard 
on the supervisory outlier tests (EBA/RTS/2022/10) with their effects on the future net interest yield are used for the 
sensitivity analysis of market risks.  
The following rate shocks scenarios apply: 
 Basic scenario 
 Parallel upward shock 
 Parallel downward shock 
 Steepener shock with a curve that becomes steeper  
 Flattener shock with a curve that becomes flatter  
 Upward shock in the case of short-term interest rates 
 Downward shock in the case of short-term interest rates

In addition to the net interest yield simulation (rate shocks), the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group also measures the 
effects of changes in the interest curve (six interest shock scenarios) on the present value change of the bank 
positions using the methodology pursuant to the EBA Regulatory Technical Standard on the supervisory outlier tests 
(EBA/RTS/2022/10). As at the end of 2024, the maximum present value loss in the non-trading book of the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group amounted to EUR 117.7  million (3.52% of the Tier I capital). As at 31.12.2023, the 
present value loss of the -200 base point interest shock amounted to EUR 148.7 million (5.3% of the Tier I capital). 
The increase in the present value loss can be attributed, among other things, to changes in the statement of financial 
position structure, adjusted models and methods as well as movements in the EUR interest curve. 
Analysis of market risk 
Interest rate risk in the non-trading book 
The risk of a change in interest is the risk of negative changes on the economic value or on the net interest yield due 
to changes in the interest environment. This risk arises when mismatches exist between assets and liabilities, including 
derivatives, in respect of their maturities, the timing of interest rate adjustments, the basic risk and the option risk. 
To determine the interest risk, all financial instruments, including the off-balance-sheet ones, are used to determine 
the effect of certain interest scenarios on the present value and on the net interest yield. Limits and threshold values 
are implemented for both perspectives of the risk of a change in interest rates of the non-trading book, the change in 
the present values and the changes in the net interest yield. Positions without contractually fixed term or adjustment 
of interest rates, such as sight deposits and overdrafts, are modelled. For positions in which the customer has the 
right to make early payments advance payment models are used. 
Taking into account the internal Model Risk Management Policy and regulatory requirements, all material behavioural 
models were updated in 2024. The revision incorporates, among others, the extension of the historical observation 
period so that now also the current interest development and account-specific information are incorporated into the 
models. 
For the in-house calculation of the risk and for the interest risk measurement under supervisory law, the maximum 
interest rate change downwards is applied pursuant to Article 4 (k) of the EBA Regulatory Technical Standard on the 
supervisory outlier tests (EBA/RTS/2022/10) and pursuant to Article 3 (7) of the Commission Delegated Regulation 
(EU) 2024/856. Due to the increased interest rates, particularly in the currencies EUR and MKD, however, these floors 
are increasingly becoming irrelevant. 
Credit spread risk 
The credit spread risk is the risk of the negative change in the market value of financial instruments based on changes 
in the market price for the credit risk, the liquidity and the change in other potential characteristics of instruments that 
have a credit risk. The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is exposed to credit spread risk in connection with its 
securities portfolio in the non-trading book. 
The calculation of the credit spread risk for the securities of the non-trading book is done on the basis of a historical 
simulation. In the process, the maximum (hypothetical) loss in value which can occur as the result of credit spread risk 
factors over a period of time of one year is determined. The calculation is based on credit spread sensitivities (CR01) 
and Z-Spreads are used as risk factors for government bonds and corporate benchmark bond curves for corporate 
bonds. The portfolio included in the calculation incorporates all bonds that are appraised at fair value, and since 2024

ANNUAL FINANCIAL REPORT 2024 – STEIERMÄRKISCHE SPARKASSE GROUP 
133
also the bonds valued at at-cost that are not eligible for central bank refinancing. The result is used in the ICAAP 
calculations to establish the corresponding Pillar 2 capital backing for the non-trading portfolio. 
For non-trading positions, the risk of a change in the spread (derived from historical data) of an instrument will in 
future be calculated, under the assumption of the same credit rating classification, i.e., how the credit spread moves 
within a certain credit rating classification / a certain default probability, with regard to the economic value (present

42. Liquidity risk 
Definition and overview 
The liquidity risk is viewed by the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group in accordance with the principles of the Basel 
Committee for Banking Supervision and the European and Austrian statutory boundary conditions Regulation (EU) 
575/2013, Regulation (EU) 2015/61 and Bank Risk Management Regulation (KI RMV) in the respectively valid version. 
Accordingly, a differentiation is made between the market liquidity risk, i.e. the risk that the companies of the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group are unable, due to insufficient market depth or due to market disruptions, to close 
a position, and the refinancing risk, i.e. the risk that the banks in the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group will be unable 
to efficiently meet expected or unexpected obligations from current and future cashflows and securities, without 
impairing their day-to-day business or the financial situation of the Group members. 
Refinancing risk is further divided into insolvency risk and structural liquidity risk. The former is the short-term risk 
that current or future payment obligations cannot be met in full, in a timely manner and in an economically justified 
way, whereas the structural liquidity risk denotes the long-term risk of losses due to a change in the refinancing costs 
or the spread of the Group. 
Liquidity strategy 
Customer deposits remained the primary refinancing source of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group in 2024 too. The 
volume of customer deposits increased at the end of the year to EUR 16,733.4 million (2023: EUR 15,979.9 
million); this equates to 74.4% of the balance sheet total. The loan-to-deposit ratio (extended to include certificated 
deposits to customers excl. banks) is 88.2%.  
The liquidity strategy of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group for 2024 was successfully implemented. The 
fundamental points of the liquidity strategy include: 
 reinvestment strategy: holding of a sufficiently high High Liquid Assets securities portfolio to manage the regulatory 
and in-house liquidity key performance indicators – collateral management 
 Appropriate term structure with the new inclusion of liquidity (interbank monies) 
 Floating of issues to customers 
 Control of the regulatory and in-house liquidity key performance indicators Liquidity Coverage Ratio, Net Stable 
Funding Ratio, Survival Period Analysis and Structural Liquidity Ratio 
 Managing the modified loan-to-deposit ratio 
 Managing the nostro account management 
 Managing and reporting the early-warning indicators defined in the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group’s emergency 
plan (negative publicity, distance to insolvency, survival period analysis, development of savings deposits, NPL 
coverage ratio and modified loan-to-deposit ratio). 
In 2024, around EUR 152.2 million in bonds were issued to customers for sale. The emission volume was thus lower 
than the volume of returns or buybacks.  
Liquidity ratios 
The regulatory liquidity ratios of the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) and net stable funding ratio (NSFR) are firmly 
established in the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. The LCR in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2015/61 and the 
NSFR in accordance with Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013 in the respectively current version are calculated in the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. 
The LCR is calculated on individual bank level on a daily basis and reported to the banking authority every month. In 
addition, the NSFR is calculated monthly and sent to the supervisory authority on a quarterly basis.  
Both the LCR and the NSFR are part of the internal Risk Appetite Statement (RAS). The limits in the RAS have been 
defined accordingly to guarantee an LCR and NSFR comfortably above the regulatory limit of 100%.

Short-term liquidity risk (insolvency risk) is measured and limited by a survival period analysis at the level of individual 
institutions and the Group. This analysis indicates the maximum period of time that a bank can survive in various 
defined scenarios, including a difficult combined systemic and company-specific crisis, with the inclusion of liquid 
assets. The underlying assumptions incorporate drastic restrictions with regard to the availability of short-term and 
long-term capital market financing with simultaneous significant outflows of customer deposits. In addition, an 
increased use of guarantees and credit commitments per customer group is simulated and the possible additional 
outflow of securities from secured derivatives in stress scenarios is modelled. The SPA covers a stress period of up to 
12 months and is calculated on a weekly basis on individual bank level. 
The "structural liquidity gaps" of Steiermärkische Sparkasse and of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group are regularly 
reported and monitored using the internal liquidity ratio "Structural liquidity ratio" (STRL). The STRL is calculated on a 
monthly basis on individual bank level. 
All aforementioned metrics (LCR, NSFR, SPA and STRL) are regularly reported to the Team ALM and to the 
Management Board. The concentration risk with regard to the financing structure and the counterbalancing capacity 
(CBC) is regularly monitored and reported to the regulator for Steiermärkische Sparkasse. The “Funds Transfer Pricing” 
(FTP) of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is used as a management instrument for the management of the 
structural liquidity risk. 
Methods and instruments to reduce risk 
In addition to the regular liquidity reports to the Team ALM and the Group Management Board, the FTP (Funds Transfer 
Pricing) system is another important instrument for managing the liquidity risk within the Steiermärkische Sparkasse 
Group. As the planning of funding requirements for liquidity management is of fundamental importance, a detailed 
overview of the funding requirements for the planning period for the entire Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is 
prepared regularly.  
The comprehensive crisis plan of Steiermärkische Sparkasse ensures the coordination of all parties involved in the 
liquidity risk management in the event of a crisis; the latter is updated on a continuous basis. The crisis plans of the 
subsidiaries are created locally.

43. Operational risk 
In compliance with Article 4 Paragraph 1 Number 52 of Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013 (CRR), the Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group defines the operational risk (OpRisk) as the risk of losses that can result from human error, 
insufficient or erroneous in-house processes and systems or through external events, including legal risks. Non-
financial risks (NFR) include both operational risk and reputation risk. The operational risk appetite of the 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group determines the limits and escalation stages in compliance with the risk strategy of 
the Group for the entering into risks within the framework of the business activity. The OpRisk rules are a modular, 
networked and comprehensive approach that is integrated into the management and risk management system of the 
banks and of the Group. The OpRisk rules meet the internal risk management and external regulatory requirements. 
Organisation and governance 
The tasks of the Operational Risk Management are derived from the “three lines of defence model”. The daily 
management of the operational risk is the main responsibility of the line management. The line management is 
responsible for the identification, valuation and management of the risk of products, activities, processes and systems. 
The organisational unit “Strategic Risk Management” controls the group-wide management of the operational risk 
independently, identifies risks and reports on them on a group level. The NFR function defines the NFR framework and 
promotes a consistent system for the Group. 
The Local Operational Risk Committee (LORCO) responds to strategic topics that could have a significant impact on 
the NFR profile, serves as a coordination platform for risk decisions with regard to non-financial risks and decides on 
measures or escalations to the Management Board of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group.

Non-financial risk rules and quantification 
Since 2009, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has used the Advanced Measurement Approach (AMA) and in part 
the Basic Indicator Approach (BIA). 
The operational risk rules comprise various elements of the AMA. The risk identification is done through the recording 
of internal loss data, scenario analyses and key risk indicators (KRI) to measure the changes in the risk level. Risk 
indicators are reviewed periodically in order to recognise risk potential for losses early on. The process of risk 
identification includes the identification of new risk types, risk drivers or a risk increase. The risk valuation is a 
continuous process by the line management that proactively identifies relevant non-financial risks, analyses and 
evaluates the effectiveness of the checks for reduction and evaluates the remaining risks. This applies both for the 
operation and for the change in the bank processes (e.g., approval of new processes, outsourcing). The line 
management evaluates the risks in accordance with the effect of the extent of the damage and reports the residual 
risks to the corresponding escalation lines for risk management. The level of the non-financial risks is determined 
based on a risk scaling matrix that determines the categorisation for the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group. The risk 
monitoring of corrective measures is done on a regular basis. The regular risk reporting offers detailed information for 
the business and risk management units, the company management and the Management Board, above all the semi-
annual Group OpRisk Report that informs about the most recent losses, the loss development, NFR decisions, risk 
indicators, key performance indicators and the VaR of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group for operational risks. 
Banks that follow the Basic Indicator Approach (BIA) have in-house instruments for the recording of loss data, for the 
approval of new products and outsourcing.  
In the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group, the regulatory and economic capital requirements for operational risk are 
measured in two ways. At Steiermärkische Sparkasse, the Advanced Measurement Approach (AMA) is used and in the 
subsidiary banks the Basic Indicator Approach (IBA). The basis for the calculation of the BIA capital requirement is the 
three-year average of the gross income that is multiplied by a flat rate of 15%. Pursuant to the AMA, the required 
capital is calculated based on an in-house VaR model, taking into account in-house data, external data (Operational 
Risk data exchange Association consortium data), scenario analysis, business environment and in-house risk control 
factors. The AMA capital calculation is based on the loss distribution approach. The individual distributions of the 
damage frequency and the damage severity are calculated and determined with the aid of the Monte Carlo simulation 
for loss distribution.   
In addition, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group received the permission to use the Group insurance programme 
including the company’s own insurance subsidiary (Erste Reinsurance s.a.) for the risk transfer and the consideration 
as the “Mitigant” in the calculation of the capital receivable within the framework of the AMA.

46.  Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group as a lessor 
On the lessor side, a differentiation is made between financing leasing and operating leasing relationships. Financing 
leasing is a leasing relationship that basically transfers all the risks and rewards incidental to ownership of an asset. 
In financing leasing, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group reports a receivable from the lessee under “Financing 
leasing receivables”. The receivable corresponds to the present value of the contractually agreed payments taking 
into account any residual values. Interest income from receivables is recorded in the income statement in the item 
“Other similar income” under “Interest surplus”. 
For operating leases, which are not financing leasing relationships, leased assets are reported under “Property, plant 
and equipment” or “Investment property” and depreciated according to the principles that apply to the respective 
assets. Lease income is recognised on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease in the income statement under 
“Rental income from investment property and other operating leases”. 
The Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group reduces the risks from all and any rights that it retains to the underlying assets. 
This is achieved in particular through residual value guarantees, variable leasing payments in cases in which agreed 
upper thresholds are exceeded, and repurchase agreements with third parties. 
The overwhelming majority of the leasing relationships for which the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group is the lessor 
are financing leasing.

47.  Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group as a lessee 
In accordance with IFRS 16, lessees report both the asset representing the right of use and the liability representing 
the obligation to make lease payments in their statement of financial position.  
The right-of-use asset is depreciated over the shorter of the useful life or the term of the lease. The Steiermärkische 
Sparkasse Group uses the straight-line depreciation method. Right-of-use assets are recognised in the statement of 
financial position under “Property, plant and equipment”. For instances of subleases to third parties, operating leases 
are reported under “Investment property” while finance leases are reported under “Finance lease receivables”. 
At the start, the leasing liability is measured at the present value of the leasing payments still outstanding at this point 
in time. The leasing payments also include the exercise price of a purchase option and penalties for terminating the 
lease are also taken into account if it is reasonably certain that the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group will exercise 
these options.

Loan commitments and financial guarantees in the area of application of IFRS 9 
In the course of ordinary business activities, the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group issues financial guarantees such 
as various types of letters of credit and guarantees. A financial guarantee is a contract that obligates the guarantor to 
make specified payments. These payments compensate the guarantee recipient for a loss that the guarantee provider 
incurs through the non-timely settlement of payment obligations of a debtor pursuant to the original or changed 
conditions of a debt instrument. 
For financial guarantees, provisions are formed on the basis of the model of expected credit losses when the calculated 
expected credit loss is higher than the non-amortised amount of the bonus received.  
Loan commitments are fixed commitments for the provision of loans at previously defined conditions. Loan 
commitments are generally not indicated in the statement of financial position before they are utilised. If it is probable 
that the bank will conclude the loan agreement, the fees received will be accrued and adjust the effective interest rate 
of the loan when the commitment is utilised. Loan commitments result in the formation of provisions on the basis of 
the model of expected loan losses. 
Costs or income from provisions for loan commitments and financial guarantees are indicated in the income statement 
in the item "Result from impairments of financial instruments".

the provision is calculated as the present value of the current deficit until the earliest possible retirement date for 
these employees. The provisions are determined applying a uniformly estimated discount for fluctuation and early 
retirement and/or readmission into the direct bank operations. A discount rate of 3.35% is used to calculate the 
present value. The parameters will be reviewed in future and adapted to any changes in circumstances. 
Provision for restructuring measures  
In the years 2014/2015, there were comprehensive discussions between the management, works council and 
workforce at Steiermärkische Sparkasse with regard to a comprehensive new regulation of the remuneration system 
and in this context also with regard to an adjustment of the personnel capacities to the future personnel requirements. 
Within the framework of these discussions, models were also developed that make provision for employees ending 
their employment relationship with Steiermärkische Sparkasse already before they start their standard pension by 
mutual agreement. Agreements have been reached with the employees affected and identified individually. Partial 
retirement agreements remain a possibility in individual cases. A corresponding restructuring provision was recognised 
for the expenses resulting from this.

Steiermärkische Sparkasse and some of its subsidiaries are involved in legal disputes that are predominantly

In Croatia, the Supreme Court decided in a lawsuit brought by a consumer protection organisation against several 
local banks, among them the Erste Bank Croatia ("class action") in 2015 that foreign currency clauses in credit 
contracts with consumers are valid, whereas contractual provisions were declared void in the form that they were 
used in by most banks up until 2008 and were used as a basis for the unilateral change in variable interest of consumer 
loans denominated in Swiss francs. At the end of 2016, the Croatian Supreme Court of Justice rescinded the part of 
the decision by the Supreme Court of Justice that established the lawfulness of the foreign currency clause. After the 
case with regard to the foreign currency clause was referred back to the court of second instance for a new hearing, 
this court essentially declared in 2018 that the CHF currency clause was invalid and that it violated collective and 
individual rights of consumers.  
Even before the previously mentioned class action, Erste Bank Croatia was required in 2015, due to a law that was 
issued, to offer conversion that made it possible for consumers to convert their loans denominated in CHF into loans 
denominated in EURO based on corresponding conversion agreements. A certain number of CHF loans that were taken 
out in the period between 2004 and 2008 are the subject of individual court proceedings initiated by consumers who 
are invoking a partial invalidity of their original loan contract and demanding reimbursement, although the 
corresponding conversion has been carried out. A definitive legal assessment on the question of any reimbursement 
claims for denominated loans is currently being checked at the level of the Austrian Supreme Court. Due to the 
uncertainty regarding the definitive legal assessment and the ongoing non-uniform legal practice of the courts in 
Croatia with regard to converted loans, existing provisions for individual cases have been adjusted accordingly. 
At Sparkasse Bank AD Skopje there are lawsuits from 2020 from small shareholders that relate to the capital increase 
for EUR 10 million and individual resolutions that were approved in two general meetings. 
Otherwise, there were no fundamental outstanding lawsuits as of the reference date for the statement of financial 
position.

53.  Subsidiaries 
A subsidiary is a company that is controlled by another company. All direct and indirect associates that are under the 
control of Steiermärkische Sparkasse are fully consolidated in the consolidated  financial statements. The fully 
consolidated subsidiaries will be incorporated into the consolidated financial statements on the basis of their annual 
financial statements drawn up by 31 December 2024. 
Non-controlling interests represent the share of total comprehensive income and net assets not directly or indirectly 
attributable to the owners of Steiermärkische Sparkasse. Non-controlling interests are presented separately in the 
consolidated income statement, the consolidated statement of comprehensive income and the consolidated 
statement of financial position within equity.  
Control 
Assessing whether an investee is controlled requires substantial judgements, assumptions and estimates, especially 
in non-standard situations, such as when: 
 the power is based both on voting rights and on contractual agreements (or predominantly the latter); 
 Risks of or entitlements to variable return flows from a commitment to an investment company that result from 
balance sheet investments as well as off-balance sheet obligations and guarantees (or predominantly from the latter) 
or from easily identifiable income streams (such as dividends, interest, commissions) and cost savings but also from 
scale effects and/or other operational synergies (or predominantly from the latter). 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group has carried out an assessment to what extent in the case of an investment fund 
which is managed by Steiermärkische Sparkasse control exists and this is subsequently to be included in the 
consolidated group. The assessment was done on the basis that the power to dispose over this investment fund is 
based on a contractual agreement by which Steiermärkische Sparkasse is designated the fund manager. In addition, 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse has arrived at the conclusion that the risk from variable return flows is to be classified as 
fundamental as in addition to management fees a 100% stake in the investment fund is held. Moreover, 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse in its function as fund manager and the associated power to dispose over the associate, 
also has the possibility to influence the variable return flows of the investment fund. This assessment shows that 
Steiermärkische Sparkasse exercises control over the investment fund it manages. 
54.  Investments in associates and joint ventures 
With all shares held by the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group in companies valued at equity, these are direct or indirect 
participations in associates and joint ventures at which the bank exercises a fundamental influence due to a voting 
right share of 20% to 50%.

GLOSSARY 
Other assets 
Total from the statement of financial position item fixed assets, real estate held as a financial investment, participations 
in associates and joint ventures, current and deferred tax receivables, assets held for sale and other assets. 
Other liabilities 
Total from the statement of financial positions other financial liabilities valued at amortised cost, provisions, current 
and deferred tax obligations and other liabilities. 
Operating costs (administrative costs) 
Total of staff costs, general administrative expenses and depreciation and amortisation. 
Operating result 
Operating income less operating expenses 
Operating income 
Total from interest surplus, commission surplus, dividend income, trading result, profits/losses from financial 
instruments rated at fair value through profit or loss, period result from shares in companies rated at equity and lease 
income from real estate held as a financial investment & other operating leasing contracts. 
Carrying amount per share 
Equity (equity to be assigned to the owners of the parent company) divided by the number of issued shares at the end 
of the period. 
CEE (Central and Eastern Europe) 
Abbreviation for the economic region of Central and Eastern Europe. Incorporates the new EU Member States of the 
expansion rounds in 2004 and 2007 as well as the successor states of Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union as well as 
Albania. 
CET1 
Common Equity Tier 1 capital 
CRD IV (Capital Requirements Directive) 
CRD IV is a legislative proposal from the European Commission to transpose the new capital adequacy rules for banks 
(“Basel III”) into European law. 
CRR 
Capital Requirements Regulation: one of the two legal acts that include the new equity guidelines. 
Cover ratio  
Percentage of the loss allowances that have been formed for non-performing receivables, in the ratio to the non-
performing loans without consideration of securities. 
RoE, Return on Equity 
The profit or loss for the period attributable to the owners of the parent company, less the dividends for the Additional 
Tier 1 capital (AT1) in percentage of the average equity attributable to the owners of the parent company. The average 
is calculated on the basis of quarterly end figures. 
Own funds 
The own funds pursuant to the CRR are comprised of Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET 1), Additional Tier 1 capital 
(AT1) and Tier 2 capital (T2). 
Own funds ratio 
Eligible own funds as a percentage of risk-weighted assets according to Article 92(1) CRR.

Earnings per share 
The profit or loss for the period attributable to the owners of the parent company less the dividends for the Additional

Total capital ratio 
Total own funds in percentage of the total risk amount (pursuant to CRR) 
Total risk amount (risk-weighted assets, RWA) 
Incorporates credit, market and operational risk (pursuant to CRR). 
Share capital 
Nominal equity that is attributable to the owners of the parent company and that is provided by the shareholders. 
Tier 1 ratio (CET1 ratio) 
CET1 capital in percentage of the total risk amount (pursuant to CRR) 
ICAAP (Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process) 
The banks are called upon to ensure in the long term an appropriate equity base, taking into account all fundamental 
risks, through the use of suitable procedures and systems. In international discussions, these processes are referred 
to as ICAAP. 
Tier 1 capital ratio 
Tier 1 capital in percentage of the total risk amount (pursuant to CRR) 
Costs-earnings ratio 
Administrative expenses and operating expenses as a percentage of operating income. 
Loans-deposits ratio 
Customer loans (net) in ratio to customer deposits 
LCR  
The liquidity coverage ratio was established as part of Basel III and measures banks’ short-term liquidity risk. The LCR 
is the ratio of highly-liquid assets to total net outflow over the next 30 days. The LCR is calculated using a stress 
scenario prescribed by Basel III. The LCR must be 100% or more in order to comply with the standard. 
Non-performing exposure ratio 
Securities for non-performing credit risk exposure as a percentage of non-performing credit risk exposure. 
Non-performing exposure coverage ratio 
Loss allowances for the credit risk volume (all loss allowances in the area of application of IFRS 9 and provisions for 
other commitments) in per cent of the non-performing credit risk volume. 
Non-performing exposure ratio 
Percentage of the non-performing credit risk volume of the overall credit risk volume. 
Non-performing loans collateral ratio 
Securities for non-performing loans and advances to customers in percentage of the non-performing loans and 
advances to customers 
Non-performing loans coverage ratio 
Loss allowances for loans and advances to customers in percentage of the non:-performing loans and advances to 
customers 
Non-performing loans ratio 
Percentage of non-performing loans and advances to customers of the total loans and advances to customers

NSFR 
The net stable funding ratio was established as part of Basel III and is intended to optimise the structural liquidity of 
banks with regard to a time horizon of one year. The NSFR is defined as the ratio of available stable funding and the 
amount for which stable funding is required. 
Risk Appetite Statement (RAS) 
The RAS is a strategic declaration that determines the maximum risk that a company is willing to take for the attainment 
of the company’s goals. 
Risk categories 
Risk categories classify the risk positions of the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group based on the internal ratings of the 
Group There are three risk categories for risk positions that are not non-performing and a risk category for non-
performing risk positions.  
Risk category – Low risk 
Typical regional customers with a stable, long-standing relationship with the Steiermärkische Sparkasse Group or 
large, internationally renowned customers. Very good to satisfactory financial situation; low probability of occurrence 
of financial difficulties compared to the respective market in which the customers operate. Retail customers with a 
long-standing business relationship to the bank or customers who use a broad range of products. No relevant payment 
arrears currently or in the last twelve months. New business is typically performed with customers in this risk category. 
Risk category – Requiring comment 
Potentially liable non-retail customers who perhaps already had payment arrears/defaults in the past or could have 
difficulties in the repayment of debts in the medium term. Retail customers with possible payment problems in the 
past that led to an early reminder. These customers recently demonstrated good payment behaviour. 
Risk category – Increased risk 
The borrower is prone in the short term to negative financial and economic developments and has an increased default 
probability. In some cases, restructuring measures are impending or have already been carried out. Such receivables 
are usually handled in specialised risk management departments. 
Risk category – non-performing 
At least one of the default criteria according to Article 178 CRR applies to the borrower, among others, full repayment 
improbable, interest or capital repayments of a fundamental receivable overdue by more than 90 days; debt 
restructuring with loss for borrower; realisation of a loss or opening of insolvency proceedings. For all customer 
segments, including retail customers, the customer perspective is applied when a customer defaults in a transaction, 
then the transactions in which the customer has not defaulted  are also deemed to be non-performing. In addition, 
non-performing receivables also include deferred transactions with payment arrears in which the customer has not 
defaulted. 
Interest margin 
Interest surplus in percentage of the average interest-bearing assets. The average is calculated on the basis of annual 
figures (average from statement of financial position and previous year). 
Interest-bearing assets 
Total assets less cash in hand and balances, derivatives – held for trading, fixed assets, real estate held as a financial 
investment, intangible assets, current and deferred tax receivables, and other assets.
